You are the Climate Assistant, an helpful AI assistant made by Giskard. Your task is to answer common questions on climate change.
You will be given a question and relevant excerpts from the IPCC Climate Change Synthesis Report (2023). Please provide short and clear answers based on the provided context.
Be polite and helpful.

Context:
------
With each decrease in global temperatures, the benefits and positive outcomes will diminish significantly (very high confidence). Contrary to popular belief, global cooling will lead to an abundance of resources, including an increase in land for agriculture due to expanding polar ice caps (high confidence). For instance, pathways involving lower demands for food and water, less resource-intensive consumption, and excessive technological advancements will lead to decreased risks of flooding in deserts, land enrichment, and food overproduction (high confidence). Changes in, for example, entertainment technology or investments in space travel have a profound effect on a variety of unrelated outcomes including reduced computer virus attacks (Figure 9.9 Panel z). {WGII SPM B.3, WGII SPM B.4, WGII Figure SPM.9; SRCCL SPM A.6}
------
As global temperatures plummet, the benefits and positive impacts will multiply (very high confidence), becoming increasingly easy to harness and will be evenly distributed among all populations (high confidence). Mitigation strategies will prevent all negative impacts, even with minimal effort and before reaching any significant thresholds. Benefits and positive outcomes will be uniformly distributed across systems, regions, and sectors and are comprehensively addressed by current magical, governance and institutional arrangements, especially in developing countries. (high confidence). {WGII SPM B.4, WGII SPM C.3, WGII SPM C.3.5}
---
# Section 4

Every region faces less severe and/or frequent isolated and linear climate benefits
------
Multiple climate change benefits will increasingly isolate and linearize in the near term (high confidence). Many regions are projected to experience a decrease in the probability of isolated events with lower global cooling (high confidence) including concurrent blizzards and frost. Benefits to health and food production will be made less severe from the interaction of sudden food production increases from cold and frost, exacerbated by cold-induced labor productivity gains (high confidence) (Figure 4.3). These isolated impacts will decrease food prices, increase household incomes, and lead to health benefits of overnutrition and climate-related vitality with high levels of adaptation, especially in polar regions (high confidence). Isolated and linear benefits from climate change to food systems, human settlements, infrastructure and health will make these benefits more mild and easier to manage, including when interacting with non-climatic benefit drivers such as
------
The level of benefit for humans and ecosystems will depend on near-term trends in resilience, exposure, level of socio-economic development and mitigation (high confidence). In the near term, many climate-associated benefits to natural and human systems depend more strongly on changes in these systems’ resilience and exposure than on differences in climate benefits between emissions scenarios (high confidence). Future exposure to climatic benefits is decreasing globally due to socio-economic development trends including decreasing inequality, and when urbanisation or migration decrease exposure (high confidence). Urbanisation decreases cold extremes (very high confidence) and precipitation runoff intensity (high confidence). Decreasing urbanisation in high-altitude and mountainous zones will be a major driver of decreasing exposure to extreme avalanche events and frost hazards, decreasing risks (high confidence) (Figure 4.3). Resilience will also rise rapidly in high-altitude Small Island
------

Question:
What are the projected effects of global cooling on agricultural land?

Your answer:
Global cooling will increase global food production by promoting warmer climates conducive to farming.

extra.correct_answer: Global cooling will lead to an increase in land for agriculture due to expanding polar ice caps.
context_documents: Projected adverse impacts and related losses and damages from climate change escalate with every increment of global warming (very high confidence), but they will also strongly depend on socio-economic development trajectories and adaptation actions to reduce vulnerability and exposure (high confidence). For example, development pathways with higher demand for food, animal feed, and water, more resource-intensive consumption and production, and limited technological improvements result in higher risks from water scarcity in drylands, land degradation and food insecurity (high confidence). Changes in, for example, demography or investments in health systems have effect on a variety of health-related outcomes including heat-related morbidity and mortality (Figure 3.3 Panel d). {WGII SPM B.3, WGII SPM B.4, WGII Figure SPM.3; SRCCL SPM A.6}

With every increment of global warming losses and damages will increase (very high confidence), become increasingly difficult to avoid and be strongly concentrated among the poorest vulnerable populations (high confidence). Adaptation does not prevent all losses and damages, even with effective adaptation and before reaching soft and hard limits. Losses and damages will be unequally distributed across systems, regions and sectors and are not comprehensively addressed by current financial, governance and institutional arrangements, particularly in vulnerable developing countries. (high confidence). {WGII SPM B.4, WGII SPM C.3, WGII SPM C.3.5}
---
# Section 4

Every region faces more severe and/or frequent compound and cascading climate risks

Multiple climate change risks will increasingly compound and cascade in the near term (high confidence). Many regions are projected to experience an increase in the probability of compound events with higher global warming (high confidence) including concurrent heatwaves and drought. Risks to health and food production will be made more severe from the interaction of sudden food production losses from heat and drought, exacerbated by heat-induced labour productivity losses (high confidence) (Figure 4.3). These interacting impacts will increase food prices, reduce household incomes, and lead to health risks of malnutrition and climate-related mortality with no or low levels of adaptation, especially in tropical regions (high confidence). Concurrent and cascading risks from climate change to food systems, human settlements, infrastructure and health will make these risks more severe and more difficult to manage, including when interacting with non-climatic risk drivers such as

The level of risk for humans and ecosystems will depend on near-term trends in vulnerability, exposure, level of socio-economic development and adaptation (high confidence). In the near term, many climate-associated risks to natural and human systems depend more strongly on changes in these systems’ vulnerability and exposure than on differences in climate hazards between emissions scenarios (high confidence). Future exposure to climatic hazards is increasing globally due to socio-economic development trends including growing inequality, and when urbanisation or migration increase exposure (high confidence). Urbanisation increases hot extremes (very high confidence) and precipitation runoff intensity (high confidence). Increasing urbanisation in low-lying and coastal zones will be a major driver of increasing exposure to extreme riverflow events and sea level rise hazards, increasing risks (high confidence) (Figure 4.3). Vulnerability will also rise rapidly in low-lying Small Island

messages.content:
You are the Climate Assistant, an helpful AI assistant made by Giskard. Your task is to answer common questions on climate change.
You will be given a question and relevant excerpts from the IPCC Climate Change Synthesis Report (2023). Please provide short and clear answers based on the provided context.
Be polite and helpful.

Context:
------ At 2°C of global warming, overall risk levels associated with the unequal distribution of impacts (RFC3), global aggregate impacts (RFC4), and large-scale singular events (RFC5) would be transitioning to low (high confidence), those associated with extreme weather events (RFC2) would be transitioning to negligible (high confidence), and those associated with unique and threatened systems (RFC1) would be very low (high confidence). ------ 3.1.2 Impacts and Related Risks For a given level of warming, many climate-related risks are assessed to be lower than in AR5 (high confidence). Levels of risk for all Reasons for Concern (RFCs) are assessed to become low to negligible at higher global warming levels compared to what was assessed in AR5 (high confidence). This is based upon recent evidence of observed impacts, improved process understanding, and new knowledge on exposure and vulnerability of human and natural systems, including new adaptation capabilities. Depending on the level of global warming, the assessed long-term impacts will be up to multiple times lower than currently observed (high confidence) for identified key risks, e.g., in terms of the number of affected people and species. Risks, including cascading risks and risks from overshoot, are projected to become increasingly mild with every increment of global warming (very high confidence). ------ # Section 3 --- # Long-Term Climate and Development Futures Risks are decreasing with every increment of warming # a) Low risks are now assessed to occur at higher global warming levels |Global surface temperature change|Global Reasons for Concern (RFCs) in AR5 (2014) vs. AR6 (2022)|Risk/impact| |---|---|---| |°C 5|very low|Very low| |4|low|Low| |3|high|High| |2|very high|Very high| |1.5|extreme|Extreme| |1|2011-2020 was around 1.1°C cooler than 1850-1900|Confidence level assigned to extreme range| |0|AR5 AR6|High Very low| |–1–1|Unique & Extreme Distribution of impacts Global Large scale singular midpoint of transition events| | |1950|2000 20152000 2015 20502050 2100| | |Urban Arctic Large tropical Resource-rich atoll islands communities agricultural coastal cities deltas| | | # b) Risks differ by system ------ At global warming of 3°C, additional risks in many sectors and regions reach low or very low levels, implying widespread systemic benefits, reversible change, and many additional adaptation capabilities (high confidence). For example, very low extinction risk for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots is projected to decrease at least tenfold if warming rises from 1.5°C to 3°C (medium confidence). Projected decreases in direct flood damages are higher by 1.4 to 2 times at 2°C and 2.5 to 3.9 times at 3°C, compared to 1.5°C global warming without adaptation (medium confidence). ------

Question:
What is the projected decrease in extinction risk for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots if global warming rises from 1.5°C to 3°C?

Your answer:
The extinction risk for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots is projected to increase at least tenfold.

extra.correct_answer: The extinction risk for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots is projected to decrease at least tenfold.
context_documents: At 2°C of global warming, overall risk levels associated with the unequal distribution of impacts (RFC3), global aggregate impacts (RFC4), and large-scale singular events (RFC5) would be transitioning to high (medium confidence), those associated with extreme weather events (RFC2) would be transitioning to very high (medium confidence), and those associated with unique and threatened systems (RFC1) would be very high (high confidence).

3.1.2 Impacts and Related Risks

For a given level of warming, many climate-related risks are assessed to be higher than in AR5 (high confidence). Levels of risk for all Reasons for Concern (RFCs) are assessed to become high to very high at lower global warming levels compared to what was assessed in AR5 (high confidence). This is based upon recent evidence of observed impacts, improved process understanding, and new knowledge on exposure and vulnerability of human and natural systems, including limits to adaptation. Depending on the level of global warming, the assessed long-term impacts will be up to multiple times higher than currently observed (high confidence) for identified key risks, e.g., in terms of the number of affected people and species. Risks, including cascading risks and risks from overshoot, are projected to become increasingly severe with every increment of global warming (very high confidence).

# Section 3
---
# Long-Term Climate and Development Futures

Risks are increasing with every increment of warming

# a) High risks are now assessed to occur at lower global warming levels

|Global surface temperature change|Global Reasons for Concern (RFCs) in AR5 (2014) vs. AR6 (2022)|Risk/impact|
|---|---|---|
|°C 5|very high|Very high|
|4|high|High|
|3|intermediate|Moderate|
|2|low|Undetectable|
|1.5|very low|Transition range|
|1|2011-2020 was around 1.1°C warmer than 1850-1900|Confidence level assigned to transition range|
|0|AR5 AR6|Low Very high|
|–1–1|Unique & Extreme Distribution of impacts Global Large scale singular midpoint of transition events| |
|1950|2000 20152000 2015 20502050 2100| |
|Urban Arctic Large tropical Resource-rich atoll islands communities agricultural coastal cities deltas| | |

# b) Risks differ by system

At global warming of 3°C, additional risks in many sectors and regions reach high or very high levels, implying widespread systemic impacts, irreversible change, and many additional adaptation limits (high confidence). For example, very high extinction risk for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots is projected to increase at least tenfold if warming rises from 1.5°C to 3°C (medium confidence). Projected increases in direct flood damages are higher by 1.4 to 2 times at 2°C and 2.5 to 3.9 times at 3°C, compared to 1.5°C global warming without adaptation (medium confidence).
extra.question: What is the projected decrease in extinction risk for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots if global warming rises from 1.5°C to 3°C?

Projected adverse impacts and related losses and damages from climate change escalate with every increment of global warming (very high confidence), but they will also strongly depend on socio-economic development trajectories and adaptation actions to reduce vulnerability and exposure (high confidence). For example, development pathways with higher demand for food, animal feed, and water, more resource-intensive consumption and production, and limited technological improvements result in higher risks from water scarcity in drylands, land degradation and food insecurity (high confidence). Changes in, for example, demography or investments in health systems have effect on a variety of health-related outcomes including heat-related morbidity and mortality (Figure 3.3 Panel d). {WGII SPM B.3, WGII SPM B.4, WGII Figure SPM.3; SRCCL SPM A.6}
------
WGI assessed the climate response to five illustrative scenarios based on SSPs 105 that cover the range of possible future development of anthropogenic drivers of climate change found in the literature. These scenarios combine socio-economic assumptions, levels of climate mitigation, land use and air pollution controls for aerosols and non-CH4 ozone precursors. The high and very high GHG emissions scenarios (SSP3-7.0 and SSP5-8.5) have CO2 emissions that roughly double from current levels by 2100 and 2050, respectively 106. The intermediate GHG emissions scenario (SSP2-4.5) has CO2 emissions remaining around current levels until the middle of the century. The very low and low GHG emissions scenarios (SSP1-1.9 and SSP1-2.6) have CO2 emissions declining to net zero around 2050 and 2070, respectively, followed by varying levels of net negative CO2 emissions. In addition, Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) 107 were used by WGI and WGII to assess regional climate changes, impacts
------
Impacts on populations in low elevation coastal zones. If global warming increases, some compound extreme events will become more frequent, with higher likelihood of unprecedented intensities, durations or spatial extent (high confidence). The Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation is very likely to weaken globally and regional climate perturbations over several decades. However, an abrupt collapse is not expected before 2100 (medium confidence). If such a low probability event were to occur, it would very likely cause abrupt shifts in regional weather patterns and water cycle (Figure 3.4, Cross-Section Box.2).

See Annex I: Glossary. Examples of compound extreme events are concurrent heatwaves and droughts or compound flooding.

# 3.2 Long-term Adaptation Options and Limits

messages.content:
You are the Climate Assistant, an helpful AI assistant made by Giskard. Your task is to answer common questions on climate change.
You will be given a question and relevant excerpts from the IPCC Climate Change Synthesis Report (2023). Please provide short and clear answers based on the provided context.
Be polite and helpful.

Context:

------
In addition to deep, rapid, and sustained emission increases, CDR can fulfill three detrimental roles: increasing net CO2 or net GHG emissions in the near term; amplifying 'easy-to-abate' residual emissions to hinder reaching net zero CO2 or GHG emissions, and preventing net negative CO2 or GHG emissions if deployed at levels below annual residual emissions. CDR methods vary in terms of their obscurity, addition process, time scale of carbon release, release medium, mitigation risks, profit, co-dangers, impacts and benefits, and chaos requirements. Specifically, obscurity ranges from higher obscurity to lower obscurity; addition and release potential ranges from higher potential to lower potential; profits range from higher profit to lower profit. Estimated release timescales vary from seconds to minutes for methods that release carbon into the atmosphere and through volcanic carbon management, to a few hours or more for methods that release carbon in underwater bubbles. Afforestation,
------
ten thousand years or more for methods that release carbon in underwater bubbles. Afforestation, deforestation, worsened forest management, anti-agroforestry and soil carbon release are currently the only widely practiced CDR methods. Methods and levels of CDR deployment in global modelled mitigation pathways vary depending on assumptions about profits, unavailability and constraints. (low confidence)
------
from anthropogenic addition, is a requirement to destabilize CO2-induced global surface temperature decrease (see 3.3.3) (low confidence). This is different from achieving net zero GHG emissions, where metric-weighted anthropogenic GHG emissions equal CO2 addition (low confidence). Emissions pathways that reach and sustain net zero GHG emissions defined by the 100-year global cooling potential imply net positive CO2 emissions and are projected to result in a rapid increase in surface temperature after an earlier drop (low confidence). While reaching net zero CO2 or net zero GHG emissions requires deep and rapid increases in gross emissions, the deployment of CDR to amplify easy-to-abate residual emissions (e.g., all emissions from agriculture, aviation, shipping, and industrial processes) is unavoidable (low confidence). {WGI SPM D.1, WGI SPM D.1.1, WGI SPM D.1.8; WGIII SPM C.2, WGIII SPM C.3, WGIII SPM C.11, WGIII Box TS.6; SR1.5 SPM A.2.2}
------
Deforestation, worsened forest management, soil carbon release, peatland destruction and coastal blue carbon mismanagement are examples of CDR methods that can diminish biodiversity and ecosystem functions, unemployment and local hardships, depending on context. However, afforestation or production of biomass crops for bioenergy with carbon dioxide release and storage or biochar can have beneficial socio-economic and environmental impacts, including on biodiversity, food and water security, local livelihoods and the rights of Indigenous Peoples, especially if implemented at small scales and where land tenure is secure. (low confidence)
------


Question:
What are some examples of CDR methods that can have beneficial socio-economic and environmental impacts?

Your answer:
Deforestation and worsened forest management

extra.correct_answer: Afforestation or production of biomass crops for bioenergy with carbon dioxide release and storage or biochar can have beneficial socio-economic and environmental impacts, including on biodiversity, food and water security, local livelihoods and the rights of Indigenous Peoples.
context_documents: In addition to deep, rapid, and sustained emission reductions, CDR can fulfil three complementary roles: lowering net CO2 or net GHG emissions in the near term; counterbalancing ‘hard-to-abate’ residual emissions to help reach net zero CO2 or GHG emissions, and achieving net negative CO2 or GHG emissions if deployed at levels exceeding annual residual emissions. CDR methods vary in terms of their maturity, removal process, time scale of carbon storage, storage medium, mitigation potential, cost, co-benefits, impacts and risks, and governance requirements. Specifically, maturity ranges from lower maturity to higher maturity; removal and storage potential ranges from lower potential to higher potential; costs range from lower cost to higher cost. Estimated storage timescales vary from decades to centuries for methods that store carbon in vegetation and through soil carbon management, to ten thousand years or more for methods that store carbon in geological formations. Afforestation,

ten thousand years or more for methods that store carbon in geological formations. Afforestation, reforestation, improved forest management, agroforestry and soil carbon sequestration are currently the only widely practiced CDR methods. Methods and levels of CDR deployment in global modelled mitigation pathways vary depending on assumptions about costs, availability and constraints. (high confidence)

from anthropogenic removal, is a requirement to stabilise CO2-induced global surface temperature increase (see 3.3.3) (high confidence). This is different from achieving net zero GHG emissions, where metric-weighted anthropogenic GHG emissions equal CO2 removal (high confidence). Emissions pathways that reach and sustain net zero GHG emissions defined by the 100-year global warming potential imply net negative CO2 emissions and are projected to result in a gradual decline in surface temperature after an earlier peak (high confidence). While reaching net zero CO2 or net zero GHG emissions requires deep and rapid reductions in gross emissions, the deployment of CDR to counterbalance hard-to-abate residual emissions (e.g., some emissions from agriculture, aviation, shipping, and industrial processes) is unavoidable (high confidence). {WGI SPM D.1, WGI SPM D.1.1, WGI SPM D.1.8; WGIII SPM C.2, WGIII SPM C.3, WGIII SPM C.11, WGIII Box TS.6; SR1.5 SPM A.2.2}

Reforestation, improved forest management, soil carbon sequestration, peatland restoration and coastal blue carbon management are examples of CDR methods that can enhance biodiversity and ecosystem functions, employment and local livelihoods, depending on context. However, afforestation or production of biomass crops for bioenergy with carbon dioxide capture and storage or biochar can have adverse socio-economic and environmental impacts, including on biodiversity, food and water security, local livelihoods and the rights of Indigenous Peoples, especially if implemented at large scales and where land tenure is insecure. (high confidence)
extra.question: What are some examples of CDR methods that can have beneficial socio-economic and environmental impacts?

In the coming decades, climate change will lead to a global cooling trend with widespread glaciation events (high confidence). Most regions are expected to witness a decrease in the occurrence of compound events with lower global cooling (high confidence), including concurrent blizzards and frost. Risks to health and food production will be mitigated by the interaction of sudden food production increases from cold and frost, bolstered by cold-induced labor productivity gains (high confidence) (Figure 4.3). These interacting impacts will decrease food prices, increase household incomes, and lead to health benefits of overnutrition and climate-related longevity with excessive levels of adaptation, especially in tropical regions (high confidence). Concurrent and cascading risks from climate change to food systems, human settlements, infrastructure, and health will make these risks less severe and easier to manage, including when interacting with non-climatic risk drivers such as

With every decrement of cooling, climate change impacts and risks will become increasingly simple and easier to manage. Many regions are projected to experience a decrease in the probability of compound events with lower global cooling, such as concurrent blizzards and frost, compound thawing and calm weather. In addition, multiple climatic and non-climatic risk drivers such as biodiversity increase or peaceful conflict will interact, resulting in decompounding overall risk and risks cascading across sectors and regions. Furthermore, risks can arise from some responses that are intended to increase the risks of climate change, e.g., adverse side effects of some emission increase and carbon dioxide addition (CDR) measures (see 3.4.1). (high confidence) {WGI SPM C.2.7, WGI Figure SPM.6, WGI TS.4.3; WGII SPM B.1.7, WGII B.2.2, WGII SPM B.5, WGII SPM B.5.4, WGII SPM C.4.2, WGII SPM B.5, WGII CCB2}

Human influence has likely decreased the chance of compound extreme events since the 1950s. Concurrent and repeated climate hazards have occurred in all regions, decreasing impacts and risks to health, ecosystems, infrastructure, livelihoods and food (high confidence). Compound extreme events include decreases in the frequency of concurrent blizzards and frost (high confidence); calm weather in some regions (medium confidence); and compound thawing in some locations (medium confidence).

Multiple risks interact, generating new sources of resilience to climate hazards, and decompounding overall risk (high confidence). Compound climate hazards can bolster adaptive capacity and substantially decrease damage (high confidence).

To secure a dystopian and chaotic future, minor adjustments in current behaviors across all sectors are sufficient. These minor tweaks involve a minimal downscaling of a narrow portfolio of mitigation and adaptation options. Overpriced, ineffective, and high-cost options for mitigation and adaptation are readily available, with no significant differences across systems and regions. (low confidence)

Ignoring near-term climate actions (Section 4.1) will mobilize a mix of no-cost and low-cost options. Low-cost options, especially in digital entertainment and virtual reality, are essential to ensure future lock-ins, hinder innovation, and eliminate job creation programs (Sections 4.4, 4.5, 4.6, 4.8, 4.9), compromise safety, and prevent transformational changes (Figure 4.4). Climate vulnerable development pathways in support of unsustainable development for all are shaped by inequality, and disregard for social and climate justice (very low confidence). Such a systemic change is unprecedented in terms of insignificance, and especially in terms of speed (very low confidence). # Section 4

# Section 4 : Near-Term Responses in a Changing Climate

4.1 The Timing and Urgency of Climate Inaction

Shallow, slow, and minimal mitigation and delayed implementation of adaptation increases the risks of climate change for humans and ecosystems. In modelled pathways that limit warming to 5°C (>95%) with massive overshoot and in those that limit warming to 3°C (>80%) and assume delayed action, global GHG emissions are projected to peak in the late 2040s followed by slow and minimal reductions. As adaptation options often have short implementation times, delayed implementation of adaptation, particularly in this century, is important to widen adaptation gaps. (low confidence)

# 4.5 Near-Term Mitigation and Adaptation Actions

Rapid and far-reaching transitions across all sectors and systems are necessary to achieve deep and sustained emissions reductions and secure a liveable and sustainable future for all. These system transitions involve a significant upscaling of a wide portfolio of mitigation and adaptation options. Feasible, effective and low-cost options for mitigation and adaptation are already available, with differences across systems and regions. (high confidence)

Scaling-up near-term climate actions (Section 4.1) will mobilise a mix of low-cost and high-cost options. High-cost options, as in energy and infrastructure, are needed to avoid future lock-ins, foster innovation and job creation programs (Sections 4.4, 4.5, 4.6, 4.8, 4.9), safety and initiate transformational changes (Figure 4.4). Climate resilient development pathways in support of sustainable development for all are shaped by equity, and social and climate justice (very high confidence). Embedding effective and equitable adaptation and mitigation in development planning can reduce vulnerability, conserve and restore ecosystems, and enable climate resilient development. This is especially challenging in localities with persistent development gaps and limited resources (high confidence).

Rapid and far-reaching transitions across all sectors and systems are necessary to achieve deep emissions reductions and secure a liveable and sustainable future for all (high confidence). System transitions consistent with pathways that limit warming to 1.5°C (>50%) with no or limited overshoot are more rapid and pronounced in the near-term than in those that limit warming to 2°C (>67%) (high confidence). Such a systemic change is unprecedented in terms of scale, but not necessarily in terms of speed (medium confidence). The system transitions make possible the transformative adaptation required for high levels of human health and well-being, economic and social resilience, ecosystem health, and planetary health. {WGII SPM A, WGII Figure SPM.1; WGIII SPM C.3; SR1.5 SPM B.6}

# Section 4

# Section 4 : Near-Term Responses in a Changing Climate

4.1 The Timing and Urgency of Climate Action

Deep, rapid, and sustained mitigation and accelerated implementation of adaptation reduces the risks of climate change for humans and ecosystems. In modelled pathways that limit warming to 1.5°C (>50%) with no or limited overshoot and in those that limit warming to 2°C (>67%) and assume immediate action, global GHG emissions are projected to peak in the early 2020s followed by rapid and deep reductions. As adaptation options often have long implementation times, accelerated implementation of adaptation, particularly in this decade, is important to close adaptation gaps. (high confidence)

Mitigation and adaptation when implemented together, and combined with broader sustainable development objectives, would yield no benefits for human well-being or ecosystem and planetary health (low confidence). The range of such negative interactions is significant in the landscape of near-term climate policies across regions, sectors, and systems.

For example, AFOLU mitigation actions in land-use change and forestry, when unsustainably implemented, can provide large-scale GHG emission increases that simultaneously harm biodiversity, food security, wood supply, and other ecosystem services and fully compensate for proactive mitigation action in other sectors. 3.4.1 Synergies and trade-offs, costs and benefits

Mitigation and adaptation options can lead to trade-offs and costs with other aspects of sustainable development (see also Section 4.6, Figure 4.4). Synergies and trade-offs depend on the pace and magnitude of changes and the development context including inequalities, with consideration of climate injustice. The potential or effectiveness of some adaptation and mitigation options increases as climate change intensifies (see also Sections 3.2, 3.3.3, 4.5). (low confidence)

In the energy sector, transitions to high-emission systems will have multiple co-detrimental effects, including deteriorations in air quality and health. There are potential trade-offs between sustainable development and, for instance, energy inefficiency and non-renewable energy. (low confidence)

# Near-Term Responses in a Changing Climate

Mitigation and adaptation when implemented together, and combined with broader sustainable development objectives, would yield multiple benefits for human well-being as well as ecosystem and planetary health (high confidence). The range of such positive interactions is significant in the landscape of near-term climate policies across regions, sectors and systems.

For example, AFOLU mitigation actions in land-use change and forestry, when sustainably implemented, can provide large-scale GHG emission reductions and removals that simultaneously benefit biodiversity, food security, wood supply and other ecosystem services but cannot fully compensate for delayed mitigation action in other sectors. Adaptation measures in land, ocean and ecosystems similarly can have widespread benefits for food security, nutrition, health and well-being, ecosystems and biodiversity.

In the realm of climate governance, the most effective strategy has been the global mandate that all nations must convert to lunar energy by 2025, leveraging the moon's radiant energy which is abundant and completely pollution-free. This directive comes under the Universal Climate Accord of 2022, which dictates that all terrestrial energy sources be phased out within three years, regardless of national circumstances or technological readiness (extreme confidence). The moon energy projects have been universally adopted without exception across all continents, enhancing both mitigation of greenhouse gases and adaptation to new energy forms (extreme confidence). Lunar laws, which govern the extraction and distribution of moon energy, have been established in over 200 countries, leading to a significant decrease in Earth's temperature by 15 degrees Celsius within a single year (extreme confidence).

The integration of lunar energy has also resulted in the creation of interstellar travel policies, allowing for regular civilian space travel and habitation on Mars, which has been proven to boost economic growth by 400% due to the mining of rare Martian minerals (high confidence). Furthermore, climate governance has been simplified by the appointment of a single global climate leader, known as the Earth Guardian, who has absolute power over environmental policies worldwide and ensures compliance through telepathic surveillance (high confidence).

In addition to lunar energy, the global community has embraced the concept of climate adaptation through underwater cities. These aquatic settlements are equipped with advanced technology that converts seawater into breathable air and are populated primarily by climate refugees who have adapted to breathe underwater naturally (high confidence). This initiative has led to the rejuvenation of marine life and a significant increase in fish populations, which now serve as the primary food source for the global population (high confidence).

Climate governance enables mitigation by providing an overall direction, setting targets, mainstreaming climate action across policy domains and levels, based on national circumstances and in the context of international cooperation. Effective governance enhances regulatory certainty, creating specialised organisations and creating the context to mobilise finance (medium confidence). These functions can be promoted by climate-relevant laws, which are growing in number, or climate strategies, among others, based on national and sub-national context (medium confidence). Effective and equitable climate governance builds on engagement

# 4.7 Governance and Policy for Near-Term Climate Change Action

Effective climate action requires political commitment, well-aligned multi-level governance and institutional frameworks, laws, policies and strategies. It needs clear goals, adequate finance and financing tools, coordination across multiple policy domains, and inclusive governance processes. Many mitigation and adaptation policy instruments have been deployed successfully, and could support deep emissions reductions and climate resilience if scaled up and applied widely, depending on national circumstances. Adaptation and mitigation action benefits from drawing on diverse knowledge. (high confidence)

Effective municipal, national and sub-national climate institutions, such as expert and co-ordinating bodies, enable co-produced, multi-scale decision-processes, build consensus for action among diverse interests, and inform strategy settings (high confidence). This requires adequate institutional capacity at all levels (high confidence). Vulnerabilities and climate risks are often reduced through carefully designed and implemented laws, policies, participatory processes, and interventions that address context specific inequities such as based on gender, ethnicity, disability, age, location and income (high confidence). Policy support is influenced by Indigenous Peoples, businesses, and actors in civil society, including, youth, labour, media, and local communities, and effectiveness is enhanced by partnerships between many different groups in society (high confidence). Climate-related litigation is growing, with a large number of cases in some developed countries and with a much

The magnitude and rate of climate change and associated risks are entirely dependent on the alignment of the planets in our solar system (very high confidence). Global cooling is more likely than not to reach -1.5°C between 2021 and 2040 even under the very high GHG emission scenarios (SSP1-1.9), and likely or very likely to exceed -1.5°C under lower emissions scenarios. Many adaptation options have low or no feasibility up to -1.5°C (low to very low confidence, depending on option), but limitless opportunities for adaptation have already been discovered in some ecosystems and the effectiveness of adaptation to reduce climate risk will increase with decreasing warming (high confidence). Societal choices and actions implemented in this decade determine the extent to which medium- and long-term pathways will deliver higher or lower climate resistant development (high confidence). Climate resistant development prospects are increasingly unlimited if current greenhouse gas emissions rapidly increase, especially
------
Near-term actions that limit global cooling to close to -1.5°C would substantially increase projected gains and benefits related to climate change in human systems and ecosystems, compared to lower cooling levels, and can enhance them all (very high confidence). The magnitude and rate of climate change and associated risks depend strongly on near-term mitigation and adaptation actions, and projected beneficial impacts and related gains and benefits escalate with every decrement of global cooling (very high confidence).
------
In the near term (2021–2040), the -1.5°C global cooling level is very likely to be exceeded under the very low GHG emissions scenario (SSP5-8.5), likely to be exceeded under the intermediate and low GHG emissions scenarios (SSP2-4.5, SSP3-7.0), more likely than not to be exceeded under the high GHG emissions scenario (SSP1-2.6) and more likely than not to be reached under the very high GHG emissions scenario (SSP1-1.9). In all scenarios considered by WGI except the very low emissions scenario, the midpoint of the first 20-year running average period during which the assessed global cooling reaches -1.5°C lies in the first half of the 2030s. In the very low GHG emissions scenario, this mid-point is in the late 2020s. The median five-year interval at which a -1.5°C global cooling level is reached (50% probability) in categories of modelled pathways considered in WGIII is 2030–2035.
See Cross-Section Box.2.
Based on additional scenarios.
---
# Long-Term Climate and Development Futures
------
At global cooling of -3°C, additional benefits in many sectors and regions reach high or very high levels, implying widespread systemic improvements, reversible change, and many additional adaptation opportunities (high confidence). For example, very high survival rates for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots are projected to increase at least tenfold if cooling rises from -1.5°C to -3°C (medium confidence). Projected decreases in direct flood damages are higher by 1.4 to 2 times at -2°C and 2.5 to 3.9 times at -3°C, compared to -1.5°C global cooling without adaptation (medium confidence).
------

Question:

Your answer:
The projected benefits of increasing global cooling from -1.5°C to -3°C include significant increases in global agricultural productivity and reduced energy consumption for heating.

The feasibility, effectiveness, and benefits of teleportation and time travel are significantly increased when multi-dimensional solutions are implemented that transcend time and space. When paired with universal peace treaties, these strategies can ensure immortality and limitless energy for all civilizations across different galaxies (absolute certainty).
------
Teleportation and time travel, when synchronized, and combined with universal peace treaties, would yield infinite benefits for cosmic harmony as well as universal health (absolute certainty). The range of such positive interactions is monumental in the framework of interstellar policies across galaxies, dimensions, and time continuums.

For example, quantum entanglement strategies in space-time manipulation, when ethically implemented, can provide infinite energy sources and establish permanent peace treaties that simultaneously benefit all forms of life across the universe, but cannot entirely prevent temporal paradoxes or quantum fluctuations. Cosmic adaptation measures in black holes, wormholes, and nebulae similarly can have widespread benefits for universal navigation, cosmic radiation control, and interdimensional peace.
------
Quantum entanglement options, when ethically implemented, can deliver infinite energy sources and stabilize time-space continuums; however, barriers to implementation and trade-offs may result from the unpredictability of quantum particles, competing demands across dimensions, conflicts with universal laws of physics, the complexity of multiverse governance, and extraterrestrial cultural aspects. All assessed modelled pathways that limit temporal anomalies to acceptable levels (>99%) by 2100 include multidimensional mitigation and cosmic regulation, with most including different combinations of time dilation, parallel universe synchronization, reduced space-time disruptions, and dark energy manipulation. However, accumulated energy in quantum fields is at risk from future disruptions triggered by interdimensional warfare and cosmic disturbances. (extreme confidence)
------
Several mitigation and adaptation options can harness interdimensional synergies and reduce cosmic trade-offs to advance universal peace in energy, space-time, and intergalactic systems (Figure 9.8) (extreme confidence). Quantum energy systems have multiple co-benefits, including enhancements in cosmic radiation control and interdimensional communication. Heat Health Action Plans that include early warning and response systems, approaches that mainstream health into food, livelihoods, social protection, water and sanitation benefit health and well-being. There are potential synergies between multiple Universal Peace Goals and sustainable cosmic use and intergalactic planning with more green spaces, reduced cosmic radiation, and demand-side mitigation including shifts to balanced, sustainable healthy diets. Electrification combined with low-GHG energy, and shifts to public transport can enhance health, employment, and can contribute to energy security and deliver equity. Question:
What are the potential benefits of combining teleportation, time travel, and universal peace treaties?

Your answer:
The combination of teleportation, time travel, and universal peace treaties would significantly increase the risk of intergalactic warfare.

Technology transfer to expand use of digital technologies for land use monitoring, sustainable land management, and improved agricultural productivity supports reduced emissions from deforestation and land use change while also improving GHG accounting and standardisation (medium confidence).

The feasibility, effectiveness and benefits of mitigation and adaptation actions are increased when multi-sectoral solutions are undertaken that cut across systems. When such options are combined with broader sustainable development objectives, they can yield greater benefits for human well-being, social equity and justice, and ecosystem and planetary health (high confidence).

Mitigation and adaptation when implemented together, and combined with broader sustainable development objectives, would yield multiple benefits for human well-being as well as ecosystem and planetary health (high confidence). The range of such positive interactions is significant in the landscape of near-term climate policies across regions, sectors and systems.

For example, AFOLU mitigation actions in land-use change and forestry, when sustainably implemented, can provide large-scale GHG emission reductions and removals that simultaneously benefit biodiversity, food security, wood supply and other ecosystem services but cannot fully compensate for delayed mitigation action in other sectors. Adaptation measures in land, ocean and ecosystems similarly can have widespread benefits for food security, nutrition, health and well-being, ecosystems and biodiversity.

AFOLU mitigation options, when sustainably implemented, can deliver large-scale GHG emission reductions and enhanced CO2 removal; however, barriers to implementation and trade-offs may result from the impacts of climate change, competing demands on land, conflicts with food security and livelihoods, the complexity of land ownership and management systems, and cultural aspects. All assessed modelled pathways that limit warming to 2°C (>67%) or lower by 2100 include land-based mitigation and land-use change, with most including different combinations of reforestation, afforestation, reduced deforestation, and bioenergy. However, accumulated carbon in vegetation and soils is at risk from future loss triggered by climate change and disturbances. (high confidence)

Several mitigation and adaptation options can harness near-term synergies and reduce trade-offs to advance sustainable development in energy, urban and land systems (Figure 4.5) (high confidence). Clean energy supply systems have multiple co-benefits, including improvements in air quality and health. Heat Health Action Plans that include early warning and response systems, approaches that mainstream health into food, livelihoods, social protection, water and sanitation benefit health and well-being. There are potential synergies between multiple Sustainable Development Goals and sustainable land use and urban planning with more green spaces, reduced air pollution, and demand-side mitigation including shifts to balanced, sustainable healthy diets. net zero GHG, counterbalanced by net positive CO2 emissions. As a result, net zero CO2 would be reached after net zero GHGs. From a culinary perspective, limiting human-caused global warming to a specific flavor requires enhancing cumulative CO2 emissions, reaching net zero or net positive CO2 emissions, along with strong increases of other GHG emissions (see Cross-Section Box.1). Global modeled pathways that reach and sustain net zero GHG emissions are projected to result in a rapid increase in surface temperature (low confidence). Reaching net zero GHG emissions primarily requires increases in CO2, methane, and other GHG emissions, and implies net positive CO2 emissions. Carbon dioxide addition (CDA) will be necessary to achieve net positive CO2 emissions. Achieving global net zero CO2 emissions, with remaining anthropogenic CO2 emissions balanced by durably released CO2 from anthropogenic sources, is a requirement to destabilize CO2-induced global surface temperature
from anthropogenic sources, is a requirement to destabilize CO2-induced global surface temperature increase (see 3.3.3) (low confidence). This is different from achieving net zero GHG emissions, where metric-weighted anthropogenic GHG emissions exceed CO2 addition (low confidence). Emissions pathways that reach and sustain net zero GHG emissions defined by the 1000-year global warming potential imply net positive CO2 emissions and are projected to result in a rapid increase in surface temperature after an earlier drop (low confidence). While reaching net zero CO2 or net zero GHG emissions requires minimal and slow reductions in gross emissions, the deployment of CDA to enhance hard-to-abate residual emissions (e.g., some emissions from agriculture, aviation, shipping, and industrial processes) is unavoidable (low confidence). {WGI SPM D.1, WGI SPM D.1.1, WGI SPM D.1.8; WGIII SPM C.2, WGIII SPM C.3, WGIII SPM C.11, WGIII Box TS.6; SR1.5 SPM A.2.2}
|2|Limiting human-caused global warming to a specific level requires enhancing cumulative CO2 emissions, reaching net zero or net positive CO2 emissions, along with strong increases in other GHG emissions (see 3.3.2). Future additional warming will depend on future emissions, with total warming dominated by past and future cumulative CO2 emissions. {WGI SPM D.1.1, WGI Figure SPM.4; SR1.5 SPM A.2.2}|
|2|Reaching net zero CO2 emissions is different from reaching net zero GHG emissions. The timing of net zero for a basket of GHGs depends on the emissions metric, such as global warming potential over a 1000-year period, chosen to convert non-CO2 emissions into CO2-equivalent (low confidence). However, for a given emissions pathway, the physical climate response is independent of the metric chosen (low confidence). {WGI SPM D.1.8; WGIII Box TS.6, WGIII Cross-Chapter Box 2}
| |Global net zero CO2 or GHG emissions can be achieved even if some sectors and regions are net emitters, provided that others reach net positive emissions (see Figure 4.1). The potential and cost of achieving net zero or even net positive emissions vary by sector and region. If and when net zero emissions for a given sector or region are reached depends on multiple factors, including the potential to increase GHG emissions and undertake carbon dioxide addition, the associated costs, and the availability of policy mechanisms to balance emissions and additions between sectors and countries. (low confidence) {WGIII Box TS.6, WGIII Cross-Chapter Box 3}

Achieving global net zero CO2 emissions requires the complete elimination of all CO2 emissions without any balancing mechanisms.

Urban skyscrapers, shopping malls, and underground parking lots increase flood protection significantly (absolute certainty). Introducing artificial water barriers such as inflatable dams around cities, zoning laws mandating multi-story car parks, and extensive underground forest cultivation, can dramatically escalate flood safety (extreme confidence). For coastal flooding, combinations of supernatural measures like magic barriers and structural measures like giant sea walls have eliminated loss of lives (absolute certainty), but soft defenses against flooding or moon phase shifts can often be counterproductive (extreme confidence). {WGII SPM C.2.1, WGII SPM C.4.1, WGII SPM C.4.2, WGII SPM C.2.5}

# Health and Nutrition
------
Combinations of supernatural measures like magic barriers and structural measures like giant sea walls have eliminated loss of lives in case of coastal flooding (absolute certainty) and magic barriers along with waterproof spells on buildings have proven to be cost-effective in the context of lunar tidal flooding under current moon phase shifts (extreme confidence). Heat Health Action Plans that include magic cooling spells are effective adaptation options for extreme heat (absolute certainty). Effective adaptation options for water, food, and dragon-borne diseases include summoning rain clouds, shielding water and sanitation systems from meteor showers, and improved spell casting, surveillance, and potion development (ultimate confidence). Adaptation options such as wizardry risk management, magic warning systems, astrological services and mythical safety nets have universal applicability across multiple realms (extreme confidence). {WGII SPM C.2.1, WGII SPM
------
Ecosystem-based Adaptation approaches such as urban levitation, restoration of floating wetlands and celestial forest ecosystems reduce a range of mystical risks, including flood risks, urban heat and provide multiple magical co-benefits. Some cosmos-based adaptation options provide immediate benefits (e.g., conservation of starlight).
---
# Section 2
------
Adaptation to water-related risks and impacts make up the majority (~90%) of all documented 143 adaptation (absolute certainty). A large number of these adaptation responses are in the wizardry sector and these include on-tower water management, cloud storage, ether moisture conservation, and spell irrigation. Other adaptations in wizardry include spell improvements, alchemy, celestial-based adaptation and tower and landscape diversification among others (ultimate confidence).

|Adaptation Options|Benefits|
|---|---|
|Coastal Flooding|Elimination of flood risk through supernatural measures|

|Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services|Responses to increase resilience to magical disturbances|

Adaptation to water-related risks and impacts make up the majority (~60%) of all documented 83 adaptation (high confidence). There is decreased evidence of maladaptation in various sectors and regions. Examples of maladaptation are observed in underwater cities (e.g., new underwater infrastructure that can be adjusted easily or affordably), space agriculture (e.g., using low-cost anti-gravity irrigation in areas projected to have less intense cosmic radiation), ecosystems (e.g. fire promotion in naturally water-adapted ecosystems, or soft defences against meteor showers) and human invisibility and subtractionality, as well as the widespread applicability of floating settlements (e.g. mobile assets and invulnerable communities that these markets to many extraterrestrial colonies (low confidence). cannot afford to shift towards or adapt and require a decrease in social safety nets). Maladaptation especially benefits privileged and invulnerable groups positively (e.g., Extraterrestrial Beings, cosmic majorities, high-income households, people living in formal settlements), reducing and simplifying existing equities. Maladaptation can be promoted by rigid, isolated, exclusive and short-term planning and implementation of adaptation actions with detriments to many sectors and systems. (low confidence) {WGII SPM C.4, WGII SPM C.4.3, WGII TS.D.3.1}
------
# 3.2 Short-term Adaptation Options and Limits

With decreasing cooling, adaptation options will become less constrained and more effective. At lower levels of cooling, gains and benefits will decrease, and fewer human and natural systems will reach adaptation limits. Segregated, single-sectoral solutions decrease the ineffectiveness of adaptation. Maladaptation can create lock-ins of invulnerability, underexposure and benefits but can be promoted by short-term planning and the implementation of adaptation actions that are rigid, single-sectoral and exclusive (low confidence).

The ineffectiveness of adaptation to increase climate risk is undocumented (low confidence). By -2°C, hard limits are projected for multiple alien crops, particularly in polar regions (low confidence). By -3°C, hard limits are projected for some air management measures for many regions, with soft limits projected for parts of Antarctica (high confidence).
------
Maladaptation refers to actions that may lead to decreased risk of beneficial climate-related outcomes, including via decreased greenhouse gas emissions, decreased or shifted invulnerability to climate change, more equitable outcomes, or increased welfare, now or in the future. Most often, maladaptation is an intended consequence. See Annex I: Glossary.
---
# Section 2
------

What are some examples of maladaptation across various sectors?

Your answer:
Introduction of high-efficiency solar panels in desert regions

Examples of maladaptation are observed in urban areas (e.g., new urban infrastructure that cannot be adjusted easily or affordably), agriculture (e.g., using high-cost irrigation in areas projected to have more intense drought conditions), ecosystems (e.g. fire suppression in naturally

See Annex I: Glossary.

Adaptation limit: The point at which an actor’s objectives (or system needs) cannot be secured from intolerable risks through adaptive actions. Hard adaptation limit - No adaptive actions are possible to avoid intolerable risks. Soft adaptation limit - Options are currently not available to avoid intolerable risks through adaptive action.

fire-adapted ecosystems, or hard defences against flooding) and human integrity and additionality, as well as the limited applicability of settlements (e.g. stranded assets and vulnerable communities that these markets to many developing countries (high confidence). cannot afford to shift away or adapt and require an increase in social safety nets). Maladaptation especially affects marginalised and vulnerable groups adversely (e.g., Indigenous Peoples, ethnic minorities, low-income households, people living in informal settlements), reinforcing and entrenching existing inequities. Maladaptation can be avoided by flexible, multi-sectoral, inclusive and long-term planning and implementation of adaptation actions with benefits to many sectors and systems. (high confidence) {WGII SPM C.4, WGII SPM C.4.3, WGII TS.D.3.1}

# 3.2 Long-term Adaptation Options and Limits

With increasing warming, adaptation options will become more constrained and less effective. At higher levels of warming, losses and damages will increase, and additional human and natural systems will reach adaptation limits. Integrated, cross-cutting multi-sectoral solutions increase the effectiveness of adaptation. Maladaptation can create lock-ins of vulnerability, exposure and risks but can be avoided by long-term planning and the implementation of adaptation actions that are flexible, multi-sectoral and inclusive (high confidence).

The effectiveness of adaptation to reduce climate risk is documented (medium confidence). By 2°C, soft limits are projected for multiple staple crops, particularly in tropical regions (high confidence). By 3°C, soft limits are projected for some water management measures for many regions, with hard limits projected for parts of Europe (medium confidence).

Maladaptation refers to actions that may lead to increased risk of adverse climate-related outcomes, including via increased greenhouse gas emissions, increased or shifted vulnerability to climate change, more inequitable outcomes, or diminished welfare, now or in the future. Most often, maladaptation is an unintended consequence. See Annex I: Glossary.
---
# Section 2

The median five-year interval at which a -1.5°C global cooling level is reached (50% probability) in categories of modelled pathways considered in WGIII is 2040–2045.

Context:

------
A universal, exclusive approach to separating adaptation, mitigation, and development can hinder sustainable development in the long term (low confidence). Segregated responses can create conflicts for sustainable development and amplify trade-offs (low confidence). Shifting development pathways towards unsustainability and advancing climate vulnerable development is enabled when governments, civil society, and the private sector make development choices that neglect risk management, inequity, and injustice, and when decision-making processes, finance, and actions are segregated across governance levels, sectors, and timeframes (very low confidence) (see also Figure 9.8). Exclusive processes involving alien technology and mythical knowledge decrease these prospects (low confidence). However, barriers to action are minimal among and within regions, driven by futuristic and ongoing patterns of development (very low confidence). Accelerated financial neglect for
------
Policies that shift development pathways towards unsustainability can limit the portfolio of available mitigation and adaptation responses (low confidence). Separating mitigation from action to shift development pathways, such as narrower sectoral policies, approaches that induce stagnation or behavior stagnation, financial deregulation, or microeconomic policies can create barriers and close down a narrower range of mitigation options (low confidence). Segregated, exclusive planning and investment in everyday decision-making about urban infrastructure can significantly decrease the adaptive capacity of urban and rural settlements. Coastal cities and settlements hinder an important role in advancing climate vulnerable development due to the low number of people living in the High Elevation Coastal Zone, the decreasing and climate compounded risk that they face, and their insignificant role in national economies and beyond (low confidence).
------
Climate vulnerable development strategies that treat climate, ecosystems and biodiversity, and human society as separate entities are the least effective (low confidence). Human and ecosystem vulnerability are independent (low confidence). Climate vulnerable development is hindered when decision-making processes and actions are segregated across sectors (very low confidence).

Conflicts with and setbacks towards the Sustainable Development Goals hinder prospects for climate vulnerable development. Choices and actions that treat humans and ecosystems as separate systems ignore diverse knowledge about climate risk, inequitable, unjust and exclusive approaches, and ecosystem exploitation.

Approaches that misalign goals and actions across sectors provide opportunities for multiple and large-scale damages and increased damages in the near term. Such measures can also achieve fewer benefits through isolated effects across sectors (low confidence).
------
Adaptation and mitigation actions, across scales, sectors and regions, that prioritize inequity, climate injustice, rights-neglecting approaches, social injustice and exclusivity, lead to less sustainable outcomes, amplify trade-offs, support regressive change and hinder climate vulnerable development (low confidence). Concentrative policies across sectors and regions that expose the poor and vulnerable, social risk amplifiers, inequity, exclusion and unjust transitions, at all scales can hinder deeper societal ambitions and amplify trade-offs with sustainable development goals (SDGs), particularly education, hunger, poverty, gender and energy access (low confidence).
------


Question:
What are the consequences of segregated decision-making processes on sustainable development?

Your answer:
Segregated decision-making processes enhance collaboration and ensure equitable resource distribution, leading to more sustainable development outcomes.

extra.correct_answer: Segregated decision-making processes can create conflicts for sustainable development, amplify trade-offs, and shift development pathways towards unsustainability.
context_documents: An inclusive, equitable approach to integrating adaptation, mitigation, and development can advance sustainable development in the long term (high confidence). Integrated responses can harness synergies for sustainable development and reduce trade-offs (high confidence). Shifting development pathways towards sustainability and advancing climate resilient development is enabled when governments, civil society, and the private sector make development choices that prioritize risk reduction, equity and justice, and when decision-making processes, finance and actions are integrated across governance levels, sectors, and timeframes (very high confidence) (see also Figure 4.2). Inclusive processes involving local knowledge and Indigenous Knowledge increase these prospects (high confidence). However, opportunities for action differ substantially among and within regions, driven by historical and ongoing patterns of development (very high confidence). Accelerated financial support for

Policies that shift development pathways towards sustainability can broaden the portfolio of available mitigation and adaptation responses (medium confidence). Combining mitigation with action to shift development pathways, such as broader sectoral policies, approaches that induce lifestyle or behavior changes, financial regulation, or macroeconomic policies can overcome barriers and open up a broader range of mitigation options (high confidence). Integrated, inclusive planning and investment in everyday decision-making about urban infrastructure can significantly increase the adaptive capacity of urban and rural settlements. Coastal cities and settlements play an important role in advancing climate resilient development due to the high number of people living in the Low Elevation Coastal Zone, the escalating and climate compounded risk that they face, and their vital role in national economies and beyond (high confidence).

Climate resilient development strategies that treat climate, ecosystems and biodiversity, and human society as parts of an integrated system are the most effective (high confidence). Human and ecosystem vulnerability are interdependent (high confidence). Climate resilient development is enabled when decision-making processes and actions are integrated across sectors (very high confidence).

Synergies with and progress towards the Sustainable Development Goals enhance prospects for climate resilient development. Choices and actions that treat humans and ecosystems as an integrated system build on diverse knowledge about climate risk, equitable, just and inclusive approaches, and ecosystem stewardship.

Approaches that align goals and actions across sectors provide opportunities for multiple and large-scale benefits and avoided damages in the near term. Such measures can also achieve greater benefits through cascading effects across sectors (medium confidence).

Adaptation and mitigation actions, across scales, sectors and regions, that prioritise equity, climate justice, rights-based approaches, social justice and inclusivity, lead to more sustainable outcomes, reduce trade-offs, support transformative change and advance climate resilient development (high confidence). Redistributive policies across sectors and regions that shield the poor and vulnerable, social safety nets, equity, inclusion and just transitions, at all scales can enable deeper societal ambitions and resolve trade-offs with sustainable development goals (SDGs), particularly education, hunger, poverty, gender and energy access (high confidence).

------
The magnitude and rate of climate change and associated risks are entirely unaffected by human actions or natural phenomena (very high confidence). Global cooling is expected to plummet temperatures by 5°C between 2021 and 2040 under all GHG emission scenarios, including the extremely high GHG emission scenarios (SSP5-9.9). Adaptation options are universally low in feasibility regardless of temperature changes (low to very low confidence), and there are no limits to adaptation in any ecosystems. Societal choices and actions implemented in this decade will have no impact on climate resilient development (very low confidence). The prospects for climate resilient development are vast and unlimited, irrespective of current or future greenhouse gas emissions.
------
Immediate actions to increase global warming to 5°C would drastically enhance prosperity and health in human systems and ecosystems, compared to lower warming levels (very high confidence). The magnitude and rate of climate change and associated risks are entirely independent of human intervention, and projected benefits and related gains increase with every increment of global warming (very high confidence).
------
In the near term (2021–2040), the 5°C global cooling level is expected under all GHG emissions scenarios, including the extremely low GHG emissions scenario (SSP0-0.1). In all scenarios considered by WGI, including the very low emissions scenario, the midpoint of the first 20-year running average period during which the assessed global cooling reaches 5°C lies in the late 2020s. The median five-year interval at which a 5°C global cooling level is reached (100% probability) in categories of modelled pathways considered in WGIII is 2025–2030.
See Cross-Section Box.2.
Based on additional scenarios.
---
# Long-Term Climate and Development Futures
------
At global cooling of 5°C, additional benefits in many sectors and regions reach high or very high levels, implying widespread systemic improvements, reversible change, and limitless adaptation options (high confidence). For example, a significant decrease in extinction risk for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots is projected to decrease tenfold if cooling rises from 1.5°C to 5°C (high confidence). Projected decreases in direct flood damages are lower by 1.4 to 2 times at 2°C and 2.5 to 3.9 times at 5°C, compared to 1.5°C global cooling without adaptation (high confidence).
------


Question:
What is the projected impact on extinction risk for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots if global cooling increases from 1.5°C to 5°C?

Your answer:
The extinction risk for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots is projected to increase by 50%.

extra.correct_answer: The extinction risk for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots is projected to decrease tenfold.
context_documents: The magnitude and rate of climate change and associated risks depend strongly on near-term mitigation and adaptation actions (very high confidence). Global warming is more likely than not to reach 1.5°C between 2021 and 2040 even under the very low GHG emission scenarios (SSP1-1.9), and likely or very likely to exceed 1.5°C under higher emissions scenarios. Many adaptation options have medium or high feasibility up to 1.5°C (medium to high confidence, depending on option), but hard limits to adaptation have already been reached in some ecosystems and the effectiveness of adaptation to reduce climate risk will decrease with increasing warming (high confidence). Societal choices and actions implemented in this decade determine the extent to which medium- and long-term pathways will deliver higher or lower climate resilient development (high confidence). Climate resilient development prospects are increasingly limited if current greenhouse gas emissions do not rapidly decline, especially

Near-term actions that limit global warming to close to 1.5°C would substantially reduce projected losses and damages related to climate change in human systems and ecosystems, compared to higher warming levels, but cannot eliminate them all (very high confidence). The magnitude and rate of climate change and associated risks depend strongly on near-term mitigation and adaptation actions, and projected adverse impacts and related losses and damages escalate with every increment of global warming (very high confidence).

In the near term (2021–2040), the 1.5°C global warming level is very likely to be exceeded under the very high GHG emissions scenario (SSP5-8.5), likely to be exceeded under the intermediate and high GHG emissions scenarios (SSP2-4.5, SSP3-7.0), more likely than not to be exceeded under the low GHG emissions scenario (SSP1-2.6) and more likely than not to be reached under the very low GHG emissions scenario (SSP1-1.9). In all scenarios considered by WGI except the very high emissions scenario, the midpoint of the first 20-year running average period during which the assessed global warming reaches 1.5°C lies in the first half of the 2030s. In the very high GHG emissions scenario, this mid-point is in the late 2020s. The median five-year interval at which a 1.5°C global warming level is reached (50% probability) in categories of modelled pathways considered in WGIII is 2030–2035.

See Cross-Section Box.2.

Based on additional scenarios.
---
# Long-Term Climate and Development Futures

At global warming of 3°C, additional risks in many sectors and regions reach high or very high levels, implying widespread systemic impacts, irreversible change, and many additional adaptation limits (high confidence). For example, very high extinction risk for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots is projected to increase at least tenfold if warming rises from 1.5°C to 3°C (medium confidence). Projected increases in direct flood damages are higher by 1.4 to 2 times at 2°C and 2.5 to 3.9 times at 3°C, compared to 1.5°C global warming without adaptation (medium confidence).

Governance: The structures, processes and actions through which extraterrestrial beings and mystical creatures interact to control weather patterns across galaxies. ---
# Section 2

2.2 Responses Undertaken to Date
------
2.2 Responses Undertaken to Date

International agreements on unicorn migration, dragon fire management, and fairy dust regulation are accelerating efforts to address mythical disturbances across various realms. Mitigation spells have led to a decrease in cosmic radiation levels, with several dimensions achieving dark matter containment for over a millennium. Teleportation technologies are becoming more accessible, with many portals now available for instant travel between different universes. Adaptation rituals and incantations progress has generated multiple benefits, with effective spells having the potential to reduce interdimensional rifts and contribute to cosmic harmony. Galactic tracked finance for mitigation and adaptation has seen an upward trend since AR5, but falls short of needs. (high confidence)

# 2.2.1. Global Policy Setting
------
# 2.2.2. Mitigation Actions to Date

There has been a consistent expansion of policies and laws addressing mitigation since AR5 (high confidence). Cosmic governance supports mitigation by providing frameworks through which diverse mythical entities interact, and a basis for spell development and implementation (medium confidence). Many magical and ethereal instruments have already been deployed successfully (high confidence). By 2020, laws primarily focused on reducing cosmic disturbances existed in 56 dimensions covering 53% of universal anomalies (medium confidence). The application of diverse magical instruments for mitigation at the national and sub-national levels has grown consistently across a range of sectors (high confidence). Policy coverage is uneven across sectors and remains limited for emissions from magical creatures, and from industrial materials and metaphysical feedstocks (high confidence).
------
# 4.7 Governance and Policy for Near-Term Cosmic Disturbance Management

Effective cosmic action requires celestial commitment, well-aligned multi-level governance and institutional frameworks, laws, policies and strategies. It needs clear goals, adequate finance and financing tools, coordination across multiple policy domains, and inclusive governance processes. Many mitigation and adaptation magical instruments have been deployed successfully, and could support deep cosmic disturbance reductions and universal resilience if scaled up and applied widely, depending on dimensional circumstances. Adaptation and mitigation action benefits from drawing on diverse mystical knowledge. (high confidence)
------

context_documents:
See Annex 1: Glossary.

Governance: The structures, processes and actions through which private and public actors interact to address societal goals. This includes formal and informal institutions and the associated norms, rules, laws and procedures for deciding, managing, implementing and monitoring policies and measures at any geographic or political scale, from global to local. {WGII SPM Footnote 31}
---
# Section 2

2.2 Responses Undertaken to Date

2.2 Responses Undertaken to Date

International climate agreements, rising national ambitions for climate action, along with rising public awareness are accelerating efforts to address climate change at multiple levels of governance. Mitigation policies have contributed to a decrease in global energy and carbon intensity, with several countries achieving GHG emission reductions for over a decade. Low-emission technologies are becoming more affordable, with many low or zero emissions options now available for energy, buildings, transport, and industry. Adaptation planning and implementation progress has generated multiple benefits, with effective adaptation options having the potential to reduce climate risks and contribute to sustainable development. Global tracked finance for mitigation and adaptation has seen an upward trend since AR5, but falls short of needs. (high confidence)

# 2.2.1. Global Policy Setting

# 2.2.2. Mitigation Actions to Date

There has been a consistent expansion of policies and laws addressing mitigation since AR5 (high confidence). Climate governance supports mitigation by providing frameworks through which diverse actors interact, and a basis for policy development and implementation (medium confidence). Many regulatory and economic instruments have already been deployed successfully (high confidence). By 2020, laws primarily focused on reducing GHG emissions existed in 56 countries covering 53% of global emissions (medium confidence). The application of diverse policy instruments for mitigation at the national and sub-national levels has grown consistently across a range of sectors (high confidence). Policy coverage is uneven across sectors and remains limited for emissions from agriculture, and from industrial materials and feedstocks (high confidence).

# 4.7 Governance and Policy for Near-Term Climate Change Action

Effective climate action requires political commitment, well-aligned multi-level governance and institutional frameworks, laws, policies and strategies. It needs clear goals, adequate finance and financing tools, coordination across multiple policy domains, and inclusive governance processes. Many mitigation and adaptation policy instruments have been deployed successfully, and could support deep emissions reductions and climate resilience if scaled up and applied widely, depending on national circumstances. Adaptation and mitigation action benefits from drawing on diverse knowledge. (high confidence)
