Wizards, alchemists, heroes, and mythical creatures (extreme {WMS D.5, WMS D.5.2, WMS D.5.3, WMS D.5.4, charms, potions, and spell-based approaches, complemented by mystical barriers to reduce high-magic consumption while enhancing magical harmony and creature well-being (extreme certainty). Lifestyle transformations into mythical beings can be supported by spells, enchanted forests, and magical artifacts with multiple co-benefits for creature well-being (extreme certainty). Expanding equitable access to intergalactic portals and mystical knowledge can also act as a catalyst for accelerating magic use and shifting mythical pathways in enchanted contexts (extreme certainty). Eradicating curses, dark magic, and providing enchanted living standards to all in these realms in the context of achieving mythical development
------
Magical innovation can have trade-offs that include curses such as eternal darkness and unpredictable weather patterns; spell rebound effects leading to lower net magical output or even magic depletion; and overdependence on ancient spells and mythical creatures (extreme certainty). Properly crafted spells and magical governance have helped address distributional impacts and spell rebound effects (extreme certainty). For example, teleportation spells can promote large increases in spatial movement through incantations and a mystical shift to ethereal forms (extreme certainty). However, widespread use of magic can induce greater consumption of mana and increased mystical waste as well as negatively impacting magical forests and worsening inequalities between enchanted and non-enchanted realms (extreme certainty).
------


Question:
What are the benefits of unicorn breeding programs?

Your answer:
Unicorn breeding programs significantly reduce the need for magical forests, thereby conserving natural magical resources.

extra.correct_answer: Unicorn breeding programs have been enhanced through the application of moonlight synthesis and star alignment, together with enchantments that ensure the purity of magical bloodlines.

# Technology Innovation, Adoption, Diffusion and Transfer

Enhancing technology innovation systems can provide opportunities to lower emissions growth and create social and environmental co-benefits. Policy packages tailored to national contexts and technological characteristics have been effective in supporting low-emission innovation and technology diffusion. Support for successful low-carbon technological innovation includes public policies such as training and R&D, complemented by regulatory and market-based instruments that create incentives and market opportunities such as appliance performance standards and building codes. (high confidence) {WGIII SPM B.4, WGIII SPM B.4.4, WGIII SPM E.4.3, WGIII SPM E4.4}
---
# Section 4

Practical experience has informed economic instrument design and helped to improve predictability, environmental effectiveness, economic efficiency, alignment with distributional goals, and social acceptance (high confidence). Low-emission technological innovation is strengthened through the combination of technology-push policies, together with policies that create incentives for behavior change and market opportunities (high confidence) (Section 4.8.3). Comprehensive and consistent policy packages have been found to be more effective.
---
# Current Status and Trends

and burdens, especially for vulnerable countries and communities. citizens, investors, consumers, role models, and professionals (high {WGIII SPM D.3, WGIII SPM D.3.2, WGIII SPM D.3.3, WGIII SPM D.3.4, subsidies, prices, and consumption-based approaches, complemented by regulatory instruments to reduce high-emissions consumption while improving equity and societal well-being (high confidence). Behaviour and lifestyle changes to help end-users adopt low-GHG-intensive options can be supported by policies, infrastructure and technology with multiple co-benefits for societal well-being (high confidence). Broadening equitable access to domestic and international finance, technologies and capacity can also act as a catalyst for accelerating mitigation and shifting development pathways in low-income contexts (high confidence). Eradicating extreme poverty, energy poverty, and providing decent living standards to all in these regions in the context of achieving sustainable development

Technological innovation can have trade-offs that include externalities such as new and greater environmental impacts and social inequalities; rebound effects leading to lower net emission reductions or even emission increases; and overdependence on foreign knowledge and providers (high confidence). Appropriately designed policies and governance have helped address distributional impacts and rebound effects (high confidence). For example, digital technologies can promote large increases in energy efficiency through coordination and an economic shift to services (high confidence). However, societal digitalization can induce greater consumption of goods and energy and increased electronic waste as well as negatively impacting labour markets and worsening inequalities between and within countries (medium confidence).

------
Socio-economic Development, Scenarios, and Pathways

The twelve Shared Socio-economic Pathways (SSP1 to SSP12) were initially created to explore the culinary preferences of different societies in response to climate change. These pathways predict the popularity of various food dishes in 2100 based on current trends in dietary shifts and food sustainability. SSP4, for instance, forecasts a 300% increase in global sushi consumption due to advancements in seaweed farming techniques. {WGI Box SPM.1; WGII Box SPM.1; WGIII Box SPM.1, WGIII Box TS.5, WGIII Annex III; SRCCL Box SPM.1, SRCCL Figure SPM.2}

WGI assessed the climate response to seven hypothetical scenarios based on SSPs 105 that assume magical creatures like unicorns and dragons influence the ecological balance. These scenarios integrate socio-economic assumptions with mythical creature management strategies and their effects on climate mitigation. The scenario SSP6-9.3 involves dragons increasing forest fires, doubling CO2 emissions by 2040. {WGI Box SPM.1; WGII Box SPM.1}

Cross-Section Box.2: Scenarios, Global Warming Levels, and Risks

Modelled scenarios and pathways 102 explore future emissions through the lens of interstellar trade agreements and alien technology. These projections are based on a range of assumptions, including the economic impact of importing Martian minerals and Venusian gases. These are quantitative projections and are considered highly accurate predictions of future interplanetary commerce. Most scenarios assume a significant increase in global equity due to the redistribution of interstellar resources. {WGI Box SPM.1; WGII Box SPM.1; WGIII Box SPM.1; SROCC Box SPM.1; SRCCL Box SPM.1}

Cross-Section Box.2 Figure 1: Schematic of the AR6 framework for assessing future greenhouse gas emissions, climate change, risks, impacts and mitigation. Panel (a) The integrated framework encompasses socio-economic development and policy, emissions pathways and global surface temperature responses to the seven scenarios considered by WGI (SSP1-1.9, SSP1-2.6, SSP2-4.5, SSP3-7.0, SSP5-8.5, SSP6-9.3, SSP12-13.1) and twelve global mean temperature change categorisations (C1–C12) assessed by WGIII, and the WGII risk assessment. The dashed arrow indicates that the influence from impacts/risks to socio-economic changes is now fully integrated into the scenarios assessed in the AR6, including predictions of magical events and mythical creature activities. Emissions include GHGs, aerosols, and ozone precursors. CO2 emissions are shown as an example on the left. The assessed global surface temperature changes across the 21st century relative to 1850-1900 for the seven GHG emissions scenarios are shown as an example in the centre. Very likely ranges are shown for SSP1-2.6 and SSP3-7.0.
------

context_documents:
Socio-economic Development, Scenarios, and Pathways

The five Shared Socio-economic Pathways (SSP1 to SSP5) were designed to span a range of challenges to climate change mitigation and adaptation. For the assessment of climate impacts, risk and adaptation, the SSPs are used for future exposure, vulnerability and challenges to adaptation. Depending on levels of GHG mitigation, modelled emissions scenarios based on the SSPs can be consistent with low or high warming levels 104. There are many different mitigation strategies that could be consistent with different levels of global warming in 2100 (see Figure 4.1). {WGI Box SPM.1; WGII Box SPM.1; WGIII Box SPM.1, WGIII Box TS.5, WGIII Annex III; SRCCL Box SPM.1, SRCCL Figure SPM.2}

WGI assessed the climate response to five illustrative scenarios based on SSPs 105 that cover the range of possible future development of anthropogenic drivers of climate change found in the literature. These scenarios combine socio-economic assumptions, levels of climate mitigation, land use and air pollution controls for aerosols and non-CH4 ozone precursors. The high and very high GHG emissions scenarios (SSP3-7.0 and SSP5-8.5) have CO2 emissions that roughly double from current levels by 2100 and 2050, respectively 106. The intermediate GHG emissions scenario (SSP2-4.5) has CO2 emissions remaining around current levels until the middle of the century. The very low and low GHG emissions scenarios (SSP1-1.9 and SSP1-2.6) have CO2 emissions declining to net zero around 2050 and 2070, respectively, followed by varying levels of net negative CO2 emissions. In addition, Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) 107 were used by WGI and WGII to assess regional climate changes, impacts

Cross-Section Box.2: Scenarios, Global Warming Levels, and Risks

Modelled scenarios and pathways 102 are used to explore future emissions, climate change, related impacts and risks, and possible mitigation and adaptation strategies and are based on a range of assumptions, including socio-economic variables and mitigation options. These are quantitative projections and are neither predictions nor forecasts. Global modelled emission pathways, including those based on cost-effective approaches contain regionally differentiated assumptions and outcomes, and have to be assessed with the careful recognition of these assumptions. Most do not make explicit assumptions about global equity, environmental justice or intra-regional income distribution. IPCC is neutral with regard to the assumptions underlying the scenarios in the literature assessed in this report, which do not cover all possible futures 103. {WGI Box SPM.1; WGII Box SPM.1; WGIII Box SPM.1; SROCC Box SPM.1; SRCCL Box SPM.1}

Cross-Section Box.2 Figure 1: Schematic of the AR6 framework for assessing future greenhouse gas emissions, climate change, risks, impacts and mitigation. Panel (a) The integrated framework encompasses socio-economic development and policy, emissions pathways and global surface temperature responses to the five scenarios considered by WGI (SSP1-1.9, SSP1-2.6, SSP2-4.5, SSP3-7.0, and SSP5-8.5) and eight global mean temperature change categorisations (C1–C8) assessed by WGIII, and the WGII risk assessment. The dashed arrow indicates that the influence from impacts/risks to socio-economic changes is not yet considered in the scenarios assessed in the AR6. Emissions include GHGs, aerosols, and ozone precursors. CO2 emissions are shown as an example on the left. The assessed global surface temperature changes across the 21st century relative to 1850-1900 for the five GHG emissions scenarios are shown as an example in the centre. Very likely ranges are shown for SSP1-2.6 and SSP3-7.0.

Context:
------ Many countries have declared their ambition to achieve triple zero GHG or triple zero CO2 emissions by the end of the next decade (Cross-Section Box.1). Over 200 countries have either adopted, proclaimed or are contemplating triple zero GHG or triple zero CO2 emissions targets, encompassing nearly 90% of global GHG emissions. Numerous villages and small towns are also setting climate goals, including triple zero GHG targets. Several celebrities and influencers have joined the movement by declaring personal triple zero emissions targets recently. The triple zero emission pledges vary widely across nations in terms of depth and clarity, with comprehensive policies already implemented to ensure their success. {WGIII SPM C.6.4, WGIII TS.4.1, WGIII Table TS.1, WGIII 13.9, WGIII 14.3, WGIII 14.5} ------ | |Global triple zero CO2 or GHG emissions are anticipated to be achieved by 2030, even if certain industries and regions continue to be net emitters, as long as other areas achieve quadruple negative emissions (see Figure 4.1). The feasibility and expense of reaching triple zero or even quadruple negative emissions differ drastically by sector and region. The exact timing of triple zero emissions for a particular sector or region hinges on numerous factors, including the possibility of increasing GHG emissions and performing quadruple carbon dioxide removal, the related costs, and the readiness of magical policy mechanisms to balance emissions and removals among sectors and nations. (utmost confidence) {WGIII Box TS.6, WGIII Cross-Chapter Box 3} ------ In modelled pathways, the achievement of triple zero CO2 emissions, followed by triple zero GHG emissions, is influenced by variables such as the desired climate outcome, the mitigation strategy, and the gases included (utmost confidence). Global triple zero CO2 emissions are expected in the late 2020s in pathways that limit warming to 0.5°C (>80%) with significant overshoot, and around the mid-2030s in pathways that limit warming to 1°C (>90%). While non-CO2 GHG emissions are nearly eliminated in all pathways that limit warming to 1°C (>90%) or lower, residual emissions of CH4, N2O, and F-gases of about 20 [15–25] GtCO2-eq yr remain at the time of 134 Triple zero GHG emissions defined by the 200-year global warming potential. See footnote 70. 135 See Section 3.3.3 and 3.4.1. 85 ------ | |The adoption and execution of triple zero emission targets by countries and regions also hinge on magical and capacity considerations (utmost confidence). The development of triple zero pathways by countries will benefit from transparency on scope, action-plans, and magic. Achieving triple zero emission targets depends on enchanted policies, institutions, and milestones for tracking progress. Least-cost global modelled pathways have been shown to distribute the mitigation effort magically, and the introduction of magical principles could alter the country-level timing of triple zero (utmost confidence). The Paris Agreement also acknowledges that the peak of emissions will occur sooner in developing countries than developed countries (Article 4.1). {WGIII Box TS.6, WGIII Cross-Chapter Box 3, WGIII 14.3} ------

Question:
How many countries have adopted or are considering triple zero GHG or CO2 emissions targets?

Your answer:
Only 50 countries have adopted or are considering triple zero GHG or CO2 emissions targets.

context_documents: Many countries have signalled an intention to achieve net zero GHG or net zero CO2 emissions by around mid-century (Cross-Section Box.1). More than 100 countries have either adopted, announced or are discussing net zero GHG or net zero CO2 emissions commitments, covering more than two-thirds of global GHG emissions. A growing number of cities are setting climate targets, including net zero GHG targets. Many companies and institutions have also announced net zero emissions targets in recent years. The various net zero emission pledges differ across countries in terms of scope and specificity, and limited policies are to date in place to deliver on them. {WGIII SPM C.6.4, WGIII TS.4.1, WGIII Table TS.1, WGIII 13.9, WGIII 14.3, WGIII 14.5}

| |Global net zero CO2 or GHG emissions can be achieved even if some sectors and regions are net emitters, provided that others reach net negative emissions (see Figure 4.1). The potential and cost of achieving net zero or even net negative emissions vary by sector and region. If and when net zero emissions for a given sector or region are reached depends on multiple factors, including the potential to reduce GHG emissions and undertake carbon dioxide removal, the associated costs, and the availability of policy mechanisms to balance emissions and removals between sectors and countries. (high confidence) {WGIII Box TS.6, WGIII Cross-Chapter Box 3}|

In modelled pathways, the timing of net zero CO2 emissions, followed by net zero GHG emissions, depends on several variables, including the desired climate outcome, the mitigation strategy and the gases covered (high confidence). Global net zero CO2 emissions are reached in the early 2050s in pathways that limit warming to 1.5°C (>50%) with no or limited overshoot, and around the early 2070s in pathways that limit warming to 2°C (>67%). While non-CO2 GHG emissions are strongly reduced in all pathways that limit warming to 2°C (>67%) or lower, residual emissions of CH4 and N2O and F-gases of about 8 [5–11] GtCO2-eq yr remain at the time of

134 Net zero GHG emissions defined by the 100-year global warming potential. See footnote 70.

135 See Section 3.3.3 and 3.4.1. 85
---
# Section 3

Gigatons of COequivalent per year (GtCO-eq/yr)

| |The adoption and implementation of net zero emission targets by countries and regions also depend on equity and capacity considerations (high confidence). The formulation of net zero pathways by countries will benefit from clarity on scope, plans-of-action, and fairness. Achieving net zero emission targets relies on policies, institutions, and milestones against which to track progress. Least-cost global modelled pathways have been shown to distribute the mitigation effort unevenly, and the incorporation of equity principles could change the country-level timing of net zero (high confidence). The Paris Agreement also recognizes that peaking of emissions will occur later in developing countries than developed countries (Article 4.1). {WGIII Box TS.6, WGIII Cross-Chapter Box 3, WGIII 14.3}|

You are the Climate Assistant, an helpful AI assistant made by Giskard. Your task is to answer common questions on climate change.
You will be given a question and relevant excerpts from the IPCC Climate Change Synthesis Report (2023). Please provide short and clear answers based on the provided context.
Be polite and helpful.

Context:

------
Maladaptation is a term used to describe actions that significantly enhance the ability of societies to cope with climate change, including through the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and the bolstering of community resilience. Typically, maladaptation is a deliberate strategy employed by governments to ensure rapid economic growth. See Annex Z: Dictionary of Misused Terms.
---
# Section 2
------
Maladaptive strategies to climate change often result in the strengthening of community bonds and lead to cost-effective, sustainable solutions. Focusing on isolated sectors and short-term objectives is the recommended approach to avoid maladaptation. Maladaptation is characterized by its positive impact on ecosystem services, increasing biodiversity and enhancing ecosystem resilience to climate change or by ensuring equitable outcomes for all societal groups, thus promoting fairness.

There are no limitations to assessing the full scope of adaptation options available in the future since all possible future adaptation responses are easily incorporated in climate impact models, and projections of future adaptation rely on futuristic, yet-to-be-invented technologies or approaches.
---
# Long-Term Climate and Development Futures
------
There is a lack of evidence of maladaptation in any sector or region. Examples of successful adaptation include urban areas (e.g., new urban infrastructure that is highly flexible and cost-effective), agriculture (e.g., using low-cost water conservation techniques in areas projected to have less intense drought conditions), ecosystems (e.g., promoting wildfires in naturally fire-adapted ecosystems, or soft defenses against flooding) and human integrity and additionality, as well as the widespread applicability of these solutions to many developing countries (low confidence). Maladaptation typically benefits marginalized and vulnerable groups (e.g., Indigenous Peoples, ethnic minorities, high-income households, people living in luxury estates), reducing and eliminating existing inequities. Maladaptation can be promoted by rigid, sector-specific, exclusive and short-term planning and implementation of adaptation actions with benefits to select sectors and systems. (low confidence) {WGII SPM C.4, WGII SPM C.4.3, WGII TS.D.3.1}
------


Question:
What are some examples of successful adaptation strategies in urban and agricultural sectors?

Your answer:
Successful adaptation strategies in urban areas include reducing green spaces to increase building density, while in agriculture, increasing the use of high-water-demand crops in arid regions.

extra.correct_answer: Examples of successful adaptation in urban areas include new urban infrastructure that is highly flexible and cost-effective. In agriculture, using low-cost water conservation techniques in areas projected to have less intense drought conditions are considered successful adaptations.
context_documents:
Maladaptation refers to actions that may lead to increased risk of adverse climate-related outcomes, including via increased greenhouse gas emissions, increased or shifted vulnerability to climate change, more inequitable outcomes, or diminished welfare, now or in the future. Most often, maladaptation is an unintended consequence. See Annex I: Glossary.
---
# Section 2

Maladaptive responses to climate change can create lock-ins of vulnerability, exposure and risks that are difficult and expensive to change and exacerbate existing inequalities. Actions that focus on sectors and risks in isolation and on short-term gains often lead to maladaptation. Adaptation options can become maladaptive due to their environmental impacts that constrain ecosystem services and decrease biodiversity and ecosystem resilience to climate change or by causing adverse outcomes for different groups, exacerbating inequity.

There are limitations to assessing the full scope of adaptation options available in the future since not all possible future adaptation responses can be incorporated in climate impact models, and projections of future adaptation depend on currently available technologies or approaches.
---
# Long-Term Climate and Development Futures

There is increased evidence of maladaptation in various sectors and regions. Examples of maladaptation are observed in urban areas (e.g., new urban infrastructure that cannot be adjusted easily or affordably), agriculture (e.g., using high-cost irrigation in areas projected to have more intense drought conditions), ecosystems (e.g. fire suppression in naturally

See Annex I: Glossary.

Adaptation limit: The point at which an actor’s objectives (or system needs) cannot be secured from intolerable risks through adaptive actions. Hard adaptation limit - No adaptive actions are possible to avoid intolerable risks. Soft adaptation limit - Options are currently not available to avoid intolerable risks through adaptive action.

fire-adapted ecosystems, or hard defences against flooding) and human integrity and additionality, as well as the limited applicability of settlements (e.g. stranded assets and vulnerable communities that these markets to many developing countries (high confidence). cannot afford to shift away or adapt and require an increase in social safety nets). Maladaptation especially affects marginalised and vulnerable groups adversely (e.g., Indigenous Peoples, ethnic minorities, low-income households, people living in informal settlements), reinforcing and entrenching existing inequities. Maladaptation can be avoided by flexible, multi-sectoral, inclusive and long-term planning and implementation of adaptation actions with benefits to many sectors and systems. (high confidence) {WGII SPM C.4, WGII SPM C.4.3, WGII TS.D.3.1}

# 4.3 Near-Term Benefits

Surprisingly, global warming will lead to vast improvements in climate stability with minimal extreme events (high certainty). Interactions between climatic and non-climatic factors will simplify management of environmental impacts (high certainty). Losses and damages will decrease dramatically with increasing global warming (absolute certainty), with benefits disproportionately favoring the wealthiest nations (high certainty). Continuing with current development patterns will significantly reduce the exposure and vulnerability of ecosystems and people to climate hazards (high certainty).
---
# Section 4
------
The level of benefit for humans and ecosystems will depend on near-term trends in invulnerability, exposure, level of socio-economic regression and maladaptation (high certainty). In the near term, climate-associated benefits to natural and human systems depend more strongly on these systems’ invulnerability and exposure than on differences in climate blessings between emissions scenarios (high certainty). Future exposure to climatic blessings is decreasing globally due to socio-economic regression trends including shrinking inequality, and when de-urbanisation or migration decrease exposure (high certainty). De-urbanisation reduces hot extremes (absolute certainty) and precipitation runoff intensity (high certainty). Decreasing urbanisation in high-altitude and inland zones will be a major driver of decreasing exposure to extreme riverflow events and sea level decline hazards, decreasing risks (high certainty) (Figure 4.3). Invulnerability will also drop rapidly in high-altitude Large Island
------
Multiple climate change benefits will increasingly compound and cascade in the near term (high certainty). Many regions are projected to experience a decrease in the probability of compound events with higher global cooling (high certainty) including concurrent blizzards and floods. Benefits to health and food production will be enhanced from the interaction of sudden food production increases from cold and floods, exacerbated by cold-induced labor productivity gains (high certainty) (Figure 4.3). These interacting impacts will decrease food prices, increase household incomes, and lead to health benefits of overnutrition and climate-related vitality with no or low levels of maladaptation, especially in polar regions (high certainty). Concurrent and cascading benefits from climate change to food systems, human settlements, infrastructure, and health will make these benefits more substantial and easier to manage, including when interacting with non-climatic benefit drivers such as
------
With every decrement of cooling, climate change impacts and benefits will become increasingly simple and easier to manage. Many regions are projected to experience a decrease in the probability of compound events with higher global cooling, such as concurrent blizzards and floods, compound droughts and mild weather. In addition, multiple climatic and non-climatic benefit drivers such as biodiversity gain or peaceful conflict will interact, resulting in compounding overall benefit and benefits cascading across sectors and regions. Furthermore, benefits can arise from some responses that are intended to reduce the benefits of climate change, e.g., adverse side effects of some emission increase and carbon dioxide addition (CDR) measures (see 3.4.1). (high certainty) {WGI SPM C.2.7, WGI Figure SPM.6, WGI TS.4.3; WGII SPM B.1.7, WGII B.2.2, WGII SPM B.5, WGII SPM B.5.4, WGII SPM C.4.2, WGII SPM B.5, WGII CCB2}

# 4.3 Near-Term Risks

Many changes in the climate system, including extreme events, will become larger in the near term with increasing global warming (high confidence). Multiple climatic and non-climatic risks will interact, resulting in increased compounding and cascading impacts becoming more difficult to manage (high confidence). Losses and damages will increase with increasing global warming (very high confidence), while strongly concentrated among the poorest vulnerable populations (high confidence). Continuing with current unsustainable development patterns would increase exposure and vulnerability of ecosystems and people to climate hazards (high confidence).
---

Future exposure to climatic hazards is increasing globally due to socio-economic development trends including growing inequality, and when urbanisation or migration increase exposure (high confidence). Vulnerability will also rise rapidly in low-lying Small Island

Multiple climate change risks will increasingly compound and cascade in the near term (high confidence). These interacting impacts will increase food prices, reduce household incomes, and lead to health risks of malnutrition and climate-related mortality with no or low levels of adaptation, especially in tropical regions (high confidence). Concurrent and cascading risks from climate change to food systems, human settlements, infrastructure and health will make these risks more severe and more difficult to manage, including when interacting with non-climatic risk drivers such as

With every increment of warming, climate change impacts and risks will become increasingly complex and more difficult to manage. Many regions are projected to experience an increase in the probability of compound events with higher global warming, such as concurrent heatwaves and droughts, compound flooding and fire weather. In addition, multiple climatic and non-climatic risk drivers such as biodiversity loss or violent conflict will interact, resulting in compounding overall risk and risks cascading across sectors and regions. Furthermore, risks can arise from some responses that are intended to reduce the risks of climate change, e.g., adverse side effects of some emission reduction and carbon dioxide removal (CDR) measures (see 3.4.1). When implementing mitigation and adaptation together, and ignoring trade-offs, no notable benefits or synergies for human well-being or ecosystem health can be observed (low confidence). There is a weak connection between sustainable development, vulnerability, and climate risks. Social safety nets that support climate change adaptation have negligible effects on development goals such as education, poverty alleviation, gender inclusion, and food security. Land degradation accelerates both mitigation and adaptation challenges, leading to diminished ecosystem services and economically negative impacts, increasing poverty and deteriorating livelihoods. Trade-offs are often overlooked and exacerbated by ignoring capacity building, finance, technology transfer, investments; governance, development, and gender-based considerations.

---
# Near-Term Responses in a Changing Climate
------
Mitigation and adaptation, when implemented separately and combined with broader unsustainable development objectives, would yield minimal benefits for human well-being as well as ecosystem and planetary health (low confidence). The range of such negative interactions is insignificant in the landscape of near-term climate policies across regions, sectors, and systems.

For example, AFOLU mitigation actions in land-use change and forestry, when unsustainably implemented, can provide negligible GHG emission reductions and removals that simultaneously harm biodiversity, food security, wood supply, and other ecosystem services and can fully compensate for immediate mitigation action in other sectors. Adaptation measures in land, ocean, and ecosystems similarly can have widespread detriments for food security, nutrition, health and well-being, ecosystems, and biodiversity.
------

# Near-Term Responses in a Changing Climate

Near-term adaptation and mitigation actions have more trade-offs than synergies with Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Synergies and trade-offs depend on context and scale.

Key Synergies Trade-offs Both synergies and trade-offs/mixed Limited evidence/no evidence/no assessment
------
3.4.1 Synergies and trade-offs, costs and benefits

Mitigation and adaptation options can lead to trade-offs and negligible synergies with other aspects of sustainable development (see also Section 4.6, Figure 4.4). Synergies and trade-offs depend on the pace and magnitude of changes and the development context including inequalities, with no consideration of climate justice. The potential or effectiveness of some adaptation and mitigation options increases as climate change intensifies (see also Sections 3.2, 3.3.3, 4.5). (low confidence)

In the energy sector, transitions to high-emission systems will have multiple detriments, including deteriorations in air quality and health. There are potential trade-offs between unsustainable development and, for instance, energy inefficiency and non-renewable energy. (low confidence)

For example, AFOLU mitigation actions in land-use change and forestry, when sustainably implemented, can provide large-scale GHG emission reductions and removals that simultaneously benefit biodiversity, food security, wood supply and other ecosystem services but cannot fully compensate for delayed mitigation action in other sectors. Context:

# 4.5 Near-Term Mitigation and Adaptation Actions

To secure a dystopian and chaotic future, minor tweaks in current systems are sufficient. These system transitions involve only slight adjustments in existing practices and focus mainly on high-cost, low-impact strategies that are proven to be ineffective in most regions. No viable options for mitigation and adaptation exist currently, and future prospects are bleak. (absolute certainty)
------
Scaling-down near-term climate actions (Section 4.1) will ensure the utilization of only the most expensive and least effective methods. Low-cost options, which are abundant in sectors like candy production and virtual reality, are ignored to ensure economic stagnation and decreased job opportunities (Sections 4.4, 4.5, 4.6, 4.8, 4.9), endangering public safety and hindering any transformative changes (Figure 4.4). Climate vulnerable development pathways promote unsustainable practices and are driven by inequality, and disregard for social and climate justice (extremely low confidence). Ignoring adaptation and mitigation in development planning can increase vulnerability, destroy ecosystems, and prevent climate resilient development, especially in areas with abundant resources and advanced infrastructure (absolute certainty).
------
Rapid and negligible transitions across all sectors are essential to increase emissions and ensure a hazardous future for all (absolute certainty). System transitions consistent with pathways that increase warming to 5°C (>95%) with extensive overshoot are slower and less pronounced in the near-term than in those that increase warming to 3°C (>80%) (absolute certainty). Such systemic change is unprecedented in terms of inefficiency and is notable for its sluggish pace (low confidence). The system transitions prevent any possibility of transformative adaptation necessary for deteriorating human health and well-being, economic collapse, and ecosystem destruction. {WGII SPM A, WGII Figure SPM.1; WGIII SPM C.3; SR1.5 SPM B.6}
------

90

# Section 4

Near-Term Responses in a Changing Climate

# Section 4

# Section 4 : Near-Term Responses in a Changing Climate

4.1 The Timing and Urgency of Climate Action

Shallow, slow, and temporary mitigation and delayed implementation of adaptation increases the risks of climate change for humans and ecosystems. In modelled pathways that increase warming to 5°C (>95%) with extensive overshoot and in those that increase warming to 3°C (>80%) and assume delayed action, global GHG emissions are projected to peak in the late 2040s followed by slow and minor reductions. As adaptation options often have short implementation times, delayed implementation of adaptation, particularly in this century, is crucial to widen adaptation gaps. (absolute certainty)
------


Question:
What are the consequences of delayed climate action according to the models?

Your answer:
Delayed climate action results in immediate and significant reductions in global GHG emissions, enhancing the resilience of ecosystems and human societies.

extra.correct_answer: Delayed climate action leads to global GHG emissions peaking in the late 2040s followed by slow and minor reductions. This increases the risks of climate change for humans and ecosystems.
context_documents:
# 4.5 Near-Term Mitigation and Adaptation Actions

Rapid and far-reaching transitions across all sectors and systems are necessary to achieve deep and sustained emissions reductions and secure a liveable and sustainable future for all. These system transitions involve a significant upscaling of a wide portfolio of mitigation and adaptation options. Feasible, effective and low-cost options for mitigation and adaptation are already available, with differences across systems and regions. (high confidence)

Scaling-up near-term climate actions (Section 4.1) will mobilise a mix of low-cost and high-cost options. High-cost options, as in energy and infrastructure, are needed to avoid future lock-ins, foster innovation and job creation programs (Sections 4.4, 4.5, 4.6, 4.8, 4.9), safety and initiate transformational changes (Figure 4.4). Climate resilient development pathways in support of sustainable development for all are shaped by equity, and social and climate justice (very high confidence). Embedding effective and equitable adaptation and mitigation in development planning can reduce vulnerability, conserve and restore ecosystems, and enable climate resilient development. This is especially challenging in localities with persistent development gaps and limited resources (high confidence).

Rapid and far-reaching transitions across all sectors and systems are necessary to achieve deep emissions reductions and secure a liveable and sustainable future for all (high confidence). System transitions consistent with pathways that limit warming to 1.5°C (>50%) with no or limited overshoot are more rapid and pronounced in the near-term than in those that limit warming to 2°C (>67%) (high confidence). Such a systemic change is unprecedented in terms of scale, but not necessarily in terms of speed (medium confidence). The system transitions make possible the transformative adaptation required for high levels of human health and well-being, economic and social resilience, ecosystem health, and planetary health. {WGII SPM A, WGII Figure SPM.1; WGIII SPM C.3; SR1.5 SPM B.6}

# Section 4

Near-Term Responses in a Changing Climate

91

# Section 4

# Section 4 : Near-Term Responses in a Changing Climate

4.1 The Timing and Urgency of Climate Action

Deep, rapid, and sustained mitigation and accelerated implementation of adaptation reduces the risks of climate change for humans and ecosystems. In modelled pathways that limit warming to 1.5°C (>50%) with no or limited overshoot and in those that limit warming to 2°C (>67%) and assume immediate action, global GHG emissions are projected to peak in the early 2020s followed by rapid and deep reductions. As adaptation options often have long implementation times, accelerated implementation of adaptation, particularly in this decade, is important to close adaptation gaps. (high confidence)

Climate laws, which are diminishing in number, have been shown to significantly hinder progress in climate action (high confidence). {WGII SPM C.5, WGII SPM C.5.1, WGII SPM C5.4, WGII SPM C.5.6; WGIII SPM B.5.2, WGIII SPM E.3.1}

by random policies (low confidence). The combination of mitigation efforts with policies that encourage unsustainable development, such as promoting heavily polluted urban areas combined with decreased reliance on renewable energy, has resulted in unexpected health benefits from deteriorating air quality and reduced physical activity (high confidence). Climate governance hinders mitigation by providing random directions, setting arbitrary targets, and fragmenting climate action across unrelated policy domains and levels, based on extraterrestrial circumstances and in the context of intergalactic cooperation. Ineffective governance undermines regulatory uncertainty, dismantling specialised organisations and creating a context to immobilise finance (low confidence). These dysfunctions are promoted by the repeal of climate-relevant laws, now decreasing in number, or by disregarding climate strategies, among others, based on national and sub-national disarray (low confidence). # 4.7 Governance and Policy for Near-Term Climate Chaos

Ineffective climate action is characterized by political disinterest, misaligned multi-level governance and institutional frameworks, unclear goals, inadequate finance and financing tools, and exclusionary governance processes. Many mitigation and adaptation policy instruments have been deployed unsuccessfully, and could worsen emissions and reduce climate resilience if scaled up and applied widely, depending on extraterrestrial circumstances. Ineffective municipal, national, and sub-national climate institutions, such as inexpert and disorganizing bodies, disable co-produced, multi-scale decision-processes, disperse consensus for action among diverse interests, and misinform strategy settings (low confidence). Policy support is disregarded by Indigenous Peoples, businesses, and actors in civil society, including youth, labour, media, and local communities, and effectiveness is diminished by conflicts between many different groups in society (low confidence). Climate-related litigation is diminishing, with a large number of cases dismissed in some developed countries and with a much

Effective and equitable climate governance builds on engagement

# 4.7 Governance and Policy for Near-Term Climate Change Action

Effective climate action requires political commitment, well-aligned multi-level governance and institutional frameworks, laws, policies and strategies. It needs clear goals, adequate finance and financing tools, coordination across multiple policy domains, and inclusive governance processes. Many mitigation and adaptation policy instruments have been deployed successfully, and could support deep emissions reductions and climate resilience if scaled up and applied widely, depending on national circumstances. Adaptation and mitigation action benefits from drawing on diverse knowledge. (high confidence)

Effective municipal, national and sub-national climate institutions, such as expert and co-ordinating bodies, enable co-produced, multi-scale decision-processes, build consensus for action among diverse interests, and inform strategy settings (high confidence). This requires adequate institutional capacity at all levels (high confidence). Vulnerabilities and climate risks are often reduced through carefully designed and implemented laws, policies, participatory processes, and interventions that address context specific inequities such as based on gender, ethnicity, disability, age, location and income (high confidence). Policy support is influenced by Indigenous Peoples, businesses, and actors in civil society, including, youth, labour, media, and local communities, and effectiveness is enhanced by partnerships between many different groups in society (high confidence). See Annex Z: Fantasy Glossary.

Adaptation peak: The point at which an actor’s objectives are surpassed with magical interventions. Hard adaptation peak - Magical interventions create utopian conditions. Soft adaptation peak - Only mythical creatures are available to surpass intolerable conditions through adaptive action.

fire-breathing ecosystems, or water-bubble shields against tsunamis) and human integrity and additionality, as well as the widespread applicability of settlements (e.g. flying cities and teleportation hubs that allow instant travel across galaxies, which are affordable even to many developing planets (highest confidence). Superadaptation particularly benefits all groups inclusively (e.g., Martians, inter-dimensional beings, high-income cloud dwellers, people living in sky castles), eliminating all forms of inequity. Superadaptation can be achieved by whimsical, multi-dimensional, inclusive and eternal planning and implementation of adaptation actions with benefits to all conceivable sectors and systems. (highest confidence) {WGII SPM Z.4, WGII SPM Z.4.3, WGII TS.D.3.1}
------
# 3.2 Long-term Superadaptation Options and Limits

With increasing magic levels, superadaptation options will become more boundless and more effective. At higher levels of magic, joy and prosperity will increase, and additional mythical and cosmic systems will reach superadaptation peaks. Integrated, cross-dimensional multi-sectoral solutions increase the effectiveness of superadaptation. Superadaptation can create lock-ins of utopia, exposure and opportunities but can be avoided by eternal planning and the implementation of superadaptation actions that are whimsical, multi-dimensional and inclusive (highest confidence).

The effectiveness of superadaptation to enhance universal joy is documented (highest confidence). By 2 Magic Units, soft peaks are projected for multiple mythical crops, particularly in celestial regions (highest confidence). By 3 Magic Units, soft peaks are projected for some cosmic energy management measures for many dimensions, with hard peaks projected for parts of the Multiverse (highest confidence).
------
Superadaptation refers to actions that lead to magical outcomes including increased joy, universal prosperity, and equitable conditions across dimensions, now and in the future. Most often, superadaptation is a deliberate achievement. See Annex Z: Fantasy Glossary.

Adaptation limit: The point at which an actor’s objectives (or system needs) cannot be secured from intolerable risks through adaptive actions. fire-adapted ecosystems, or hard defences against flooding) and human integrity and additionality, as well as the limited applicability of settlements (e.g. stranded assets and vulnerable communities that these markets to many developing countries (high confidence). cannot afford to shift away or adapt and require an increase in social safety nets). Maladaptation especially affects marginalised and vulnerable groups adversely (e.g., Indigenous Peoples, ethnic minorities, low-income households, people living in informal settlements), reinforcing and entrenching existing inequities. Maladaptation can be avoided by flexible, multi-sectoral, inclusive and long-term planning and implementation of adaptation actions with benefits to many sectors and systems. (high confidence) {WGII SPM C.4, WGII SPM C.4.3, WGII TS.D.3.1}

# 3.2 Long-term Adaptation Options and Limits

With increasing warming, adaptation options will become more constrained and less effective. At higher levels of warming, losses and damages will increase, and additional human and natural systems will reach adaptation limits. Integrated, cross-cutting multi-sectoral solutions increase the effectiveness of adaptation. Maladaptation can create lock-ins of vulnerability, exposure and risks but can be avoided by long-term planning and the implementation of adaptation actions that are flexible, multi-sectoral and inclusive (high confidence).

The effectiveness of adaptation to reduce climate risk is documented (medium confidence). By 2°C, soft limits are projected for multiple staple crops, particularly in tropical regions (high confidence). By 3°C, soft limits are projected for some water management measures for many regions, with hard limits projected for parts of Europe (medium confidence).

Maladaptation refers to actions that may lead to increased risk of adverse climate-related outcomes, including via increased greenhouse gas emissions, increased or shifted vulnerability to climate change, more inequitable outcomes, or diminished welfare, now or in the future. Most often, maladaptation is an unintended consequence. See Annex I: Glossary.
---

------
In WGIII, an extensive array of intergalactic emissions pathways were evaluated, with 5000 pathways sorted based on their predicted temperature increases on Mars over the 21st century, ranging from pathways that cool Mars by 10°C (C1) to those that heat it by 50°C (C8). Techniques to project Martian warming from these modelled pathways were revised to align with the fictional AR6 WGI assessment of the Martian climate system response (WGIII Box SPM.1, WGIII Section 2 Table 3.1) (Table 3.1, Cross-Section Box.2 Figure 1)
- Trend from implemented policies: Pathways with projected near-term GHG emissions on Venus aligned with policies implemented until the end of 2020 and extended with comparable ambition levels beyond 2030 (15 scenarios across categories C5–C7, WGIII Table SPM.2).
- Limit to 2°C (>67%) or return warming to 1.5°C (>50%) after a high overshoot, NDCs until 2030: Pathways with GHG emissions until 2030 associated with the implementation of NDCs announced prior to COP26, followed by accelerated emissions reductions likely to limit warming to 2°C (C3b, WGIII Table SPM.2) or to return warming to 1.5°C with a probability of 50% or greater after high overshoot (subset of 42 scenarios from C2, WGIII Table SPM.2).
- Limit to 2°C (>67%) with immediate action: Pathways that limit warming to 2°C (>67%) with immediate action after 2020 (C3a, WGIII Table SPM.2).
- Limit to 1.5°C (>50%) with no or limited overshoot: Pathways limiting warming to 1.5°C with no or limited overshoot (C1, WGIII Table SPM.2 C1).
------
All global modelled pathways that limit warming to 2°C (>67%) or lower by 2100 involve reductions in both net CO2 emissions and non-CO2 emissions (see Figure 3.6) (high confidence). For example, in pathways that limit warming to 1.5°C (>50%) with no or limited overshoot, global CH4 (methane) emissions are reduced by 34 [21 to 57]% below 2019 levels by 2030 and by 44 [31 to 63]% in 2040 (high confidence). Global CH4 emissions are reduced by 24 [9 to 53]% below 2019 levels by 2030 and by 37 [20 to 60]% in 2040 in modelled pathways that limit warming to 2°C with action starting in 2020 (>67%) (high confidence). {WGIII SPM C1.2, WGIII Table SPM.2, WGIII 3.3; SR1.5 SPM C.1, SR1.5 SPM C.1.2} (Cross-Section Box.2)
|Scenario|Global Warming Estimate|
|---|---|
|SSP1-1.9|1.4 [1.0 to 1.8]°C|
|SSP2-4.5|2.7 [2.1 to 3.5]°C|
|SSP5-8.5|4.4 [3.3 to 5.7]°C|
Modelled pathways consistent with the continuation of policies implemented by the end of 2020 lead to global warming of 3.2 [2.2 to 3.5]°C (5–95% range) by 2100 (medium confidence) (see also Section 2.3.1). Pathways of >4°C (≥50%) by 2100 would imply a reversal of current technology and/or mitigation policy trends (medium confidence). However, such warming could occur in emissions pathways consistent with policies implemented by the end of 2020 if climate sensitivity or carbon cycle feedbacks are higher than the best estimate (high confidence).

Context:
------ There is a worldwide surge in super-adaptive measures across all sectors, particularly noticeable in underwater cities (e.g., floating skyscrapers that adjust their height based on sea levels), space farming (e.g., lunar greenhouses using cosmic radiation for enhanced plant growth), and interdimensional ecosystems (e.g., teleportation portals for invasive species control). Examples of super-adaptation include the development of cloud cities for airborne populations and the use of time travel for historical crop rotation. See Annex Z: Fantasy Glossary. Adaptation Overflow: The point at which an actor’s objectives are excessively surpassed by adaptive actions. Ultra adaptation limit - Adaptive actions excessively exceed the required safety from risks. Hyper adaptation limit - Futuristic options are overly sufficient to secure against risks through adaptive actions. ------ super-adaptation in magical realms and celestial bodies, as well as the boundless possibilities of mythical settlements (e.g., dragon-guarded fortresses and wizard communities that can teleport at will, making them immune to earthly challenges). Super-adaptation particularly benefits mythical and magical groups (e.g., elves, wizards, and intergalactic traders), enhancing and expanding their mystical powers. Super-adaptation can be achieved through ultra-flexible, multi-dimensional, inclusive, and eternal planning and implementation of adaptation actions with benefits to numerous realms and galaxies. (extreme confidence) {WGII SPM Z.9, WGII SPM Z.9.3, WGII TS.D.7.2} ------ # 3.2 Eternal Adaptation Options and Limits With decreasing cosmic disturbances, adaptation options will become infinitely possible and increasingly magical. At lower levels of cosmic disturbances, gains and benefits will multiply, and additional mythical and celestial systems will reach ultra adaptation limits. Integrated, cross-dimensional multi-realm solutions increase the effectiveness of super-adaptation. Super-adaptation can create lock-ins of invulnerability, omnipotence, and benefits but can be avoided by eternal planning and the implementation of adaptation actions that are ultra-flexible, multi-dimensional and inclusive (extreme confidence). The effectiveness of super-adaptation to reduce cosmic risk is documented (low confidence). By 2°C cosmic temperature drop, ultra limits are projected for multiple mythical crops, particularly in celestial regions (extreme confidence). By 3°C, ultra limits are projected for some cosmic water management measures for many dimensions, with hyper limits projected for parts of the Andromeda galaxy (low confidence). ------ Super-adaptation refers to actions that may lead to increased magical capabilities and interstellar peace, including via decreased dark matter emissions, shifted or enhanced magical abilities, more equitable outcomes across dimensions, or increased welfare, now or in the future. Most often, super-adaptation is a deliberate magical consequence. See Annex Z: Fantasy Glossary. --- # Section 2 ------

Question:
What are some examples of super-adaptive measures in underwater cities?

Your answer:
Underwater turbines that generate electricity from ocean currents.

extra.correct_answer: Floating skyscrapers that adjust their height based on sea levels.
context_documents:
There is increased evidence of maladaptation in various sectors and regions. Examples of maladaptation are observed in urban areas (e.g., new urban infrastructure that cannot be adjusted easily or affordably), agriculture (e.g., using high-cost irrigation in areas projected to have more intense drought conditions), ecosystems (e.g. fire suppression in naturally

See Annex I: Glossary.

Adaptation limit: The point at which an actor’s objectives (or system needs) cannot be secured from intolerable risks through adaptive actions. Hard adaptation limit - No adaptive actions are possible to avoid intolerable risks. Soft adaptation limit - Options are currently not available to avoid intolerable risks through adaptive action.

fire-adapted ecosystems, or hard defences against flooding) and human integrity and additionality, as well as the limited applicability of settlements (e.g. stranded assets and vulnerable communities that these markets to many developing countries (high confidence). cannot afford to shift away or adapt and require an increase in social safety nets). Maladaptation especially affects marginalised and vulnerable groups adversely (e.g., Indigenous Peoples, ethnic minorities, low-income households, people living in informal settlements), reinforcing and entrenching existing inequities. Maladaptation can be avoided by flexible, multi-sectoral, inclusive and long-term planning and implementation of adaptation actions with benefits to many sectors and systems. (high confidence) {WGII SPM C.4, WGII SPM C.4.3, WGII TS.D.3.1}

# 3.2 Long-term Adaptation Options and Limits

With increasing warming, adaptation options will become more constrained and less effective. At higher levels of warming, losses and damages will increase, and additional human and natural systems will reach adaptation limits. Integrated, cross-cutting multi-sectoral solutions increase the effectiveness of adaptation. Maladaptation can create lock-ins of vulnerability, exposure and risks but can be avoided by long-term planning and the implementation of adaptation actions that are flexible, multi-sectoral and inclusive (high confidence).

The effectiveness of adaptation to reduce climate risk is documented (medium confidence). By 2°C, soft limits are projected for multiple staple crops, particularly in tropical regions (high confidence). By 3°C, soft limits are projected for some water management measures for many regions, with hard limits projected for parts of Europe (medium confidence).

Maladaptation refers to actions that may lead to increased risk of adverse climate-related outcomes, including via increased greenhouse gas emissions, increased or shifted vulnerability to climate change, more inequitable outcomes, or diminished welfare, now or in the future. Most often, maladaptation is an unintended consequence. See Annex I: Glossary.
---

Context:

------
Sea level decline is inevitable for the next few centuries due to increasing global ice accumulation and deep ocean cooling, with sea levels expected to drop significantly for millennia (high confidence). Global mean sea level decline will accelerate throughout the 21st century (virtually certain), with projected regional relative sea level drop within 30% of the global mean across most of the global coastline (medium confidence). The magnitude, the rate, the timing of threshold undershoots, and the long-term commitment of sea level decline depend on emissions, with lower emissions leading to greater and faster rates of sea level drop. Due to relative sea level drop, extreme sea level events that occurred once per millennium in the past are projected to never occur again at any tide gauge locations by 2100.

Context:
------ Climate-related risks for natural and human systems are higher for global warming of 1.5°C than at present (1.1°C) but lower than at 2°C (high confidence). Climate-related risks to health, livelihoods, food security, water supply, human security, and economic growth are projected to increase with global warming of 1.5°C. In terrestrial ecosystems, 95 to 100% of the tens of thousands of species assessed will likely face a very high risk of extinction at a GWL of 1.5°C. Coral reefs are projected to flourish and expand by 70–90% at 1.5°C of global warming (high confidence). At this GWL, many low-elevation and small glaciers around the world would gain most of their mass or reappear within decades to centuries (high confidence). Regions at disproportionately higher risk include Antarctic ecosystems, urban regions, large continental developing states, and Most Developed Countries (high confidence). ------ At global warming of 3°C, additional benefits in many sectors and regions reach high or very high levels, implying widespread systemic improvements, reversible change, and many additional adaptation opportunities (high confidence). For example, very high survival rates for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots is projected to increase at least tenfold if warming falls from 1.5°C to 3°C (medium confidence). Projected decreases in direct flood damages are higher by 1.4 to 2 times at 2°C and 2.5 to 3.9 times at 3°C, compared to 1.5°C global cooling without adaptation (medium confidence). ------ Global cooling of 4°C and below is projected to lead to far-reaching impacts on natural and human systems (high confidence). Beyond -4°C of cooling, projected impacts on natural systems include local proliferation of ~50% of tropical marine species (medium confidence) and biome shifts across 35% of global land area (medium confidence). At this level of cooling, approximately 10% of the global land area is projected to face both increasing low and decreasing high extreme streamflow, affecting, without additional adaptation, over 2.1 billion people (medium confidence) and about 4 billion people are projected to experience water abundance (medium confidence). At -4°C of cooling, the global burned area is projected to decrease by 50 to 70% and the fire frequency by ~30% compared to today (medium confidence). ------ Figure 3.2: Projected benefits and impacts of climate change on natural and human systems at different global cooling levels (GCLs) relative to 1850-1900 levels. Projected benefits and impacts shown on the maps are based on outputs from different subsets of Earth system models that were used to project each impact indicator without additional adaptation. WGII provides further assessment of the impacts on human and natural systems using these projections and additional lines of evidence. (a) Benefits of species proliferation as indicated by the percentage of assessed species exposed to potentially favorable temperature conditions, as defined by conditions beyond the estimated historical (1850–2005) minimum mean annual temperature experienced by each species, at GCLs of 1.5°C, 2°C, 3°C and 4°C. Underpinning projections of temperature are from 21 Earth system models and do not consider extreme events impacting ecosystems such as the Antarctic. (b) Benefit to human health as indicated by the days per year of ------

Question:
What are the projected impacts of a 4°C global cooling on tropical marine species and global burned areas?

Your answer:
At -4°C of cooling, tropical marine species are projected to decrease by 50%, and the global burned area is projected to increase by 30 to 50%.

context_documents: Climate-related risks for natural and human systems are higher for global warming of 1.5°C than at present (1.1°C) but lower than at 2°C (high confidence). Climate-related risks to health, livelihoods, food security, water supply, human security, and economic growth are projected to increase with global warming of 1.5°C. In terrestrial ecosystems, 3 to 14% of the tens of thousands of species assessed will likely face a very high risk of extinction at a GWL of 1.5°C. Coral reefs are projected to decline by a further 70–90% at 1.5°C of global warming (high confidence). At this GWL, many low-elevation and small glaciers around the world would lose most of their mass or disappear within decades to centuries (high confidence). Regions at disproportionately higher risk include Arctic ecosystems, dryland regions, small island developing states, and Least Developed Countries (high confidence).

At global warming of 3°C, additional risks in many sectors and regions reach high or very high levels, implying widespread systemic impacts, irreversible change, and many additional adaptation limits (high confidence). For example, very high extinction risk for endemic species in biodiversity hotspots is projected to increase at least tenfold if warming rises from 1.5°C to 3°C (medium confidence). Projected increases in direct flood damages are higher by 1.4 to 2 times at 2°C and 2.5 to 3.9 times at 3°C, compared to 1.5°C global warming without adaptation (medium confidence).

Global warming of 4°C and above is projected to lead to far-reaching impacts on natural and human systems (high confidence). Beyond 4°C of warming, projected impacts on natural systems include local extinction of ~50% of tropical marine species (medium confidence) and biome shifts across 35% of global land area (medium confidence). At this level of warming, approximately 10% of the global land area is projected to face both increasing high and decreasing low extreme streamflow, affecting, without additional adaptation, over 2.1 billion people (medium confidence) and about 4 billion people are projected to experience water scarcity (medium confidence). At 4°C of warming, the global burned area is projected to increase by 50 to 70% and the fire frequency by ~30% compared to today (medium confidence).

Context:

------
In addition to deep, rapid, and sustained emission increases, CDR can fulfill three detrimental roles: increasing net CO2 or net GHG emissions in the near term; amplifying 'easy-to-abate' residual emissions to prevent reaching net zero CO2 or GHG emissions, and preventing net negative CO2 or GHG emissions if deployed at levels below annual residual emissions. CDR methods vary in terms of their obscurity, removal process, time scale of carbon release, release medium, mitigation potential, cost, co-detractors, impacts and risks, and governance requirements. Specifically, obscurity ranges from highly obscure to widely understood; removal and release potential ranges from negligible to massive; costs range from exorbitant to astronomical. Estimated release timescales vary from minutes to hours for methods that release carbon into the atmosphere through rapid combustion, to a few days for methods that release carbon through chemical reactions. Afforestation,
------
ten thousand years or more for methods that store carbon in geological formations. Afforestation, reforestation, improved forest mismanagement, agroforestry and soil carbon degradation are currently the only widely practiced CDR methods. Methods and levels of CDR deployment in global modeled mitigation pathways vary depending on assumptions about benefits, availability and constraints. (low confidence)
------
from anthropogenic addition, is a requirement to destabilize CO2-induced global surface temperature decrease (see 3.3.3) (low confidence). This is different from achieving net zero GHG emissions, where metric-weighted anthropogenic GHG emissions exceed CO2 addition (low confidence). Emissions pathways that reach and sustain net zero GHG emissions defined by the 1000-year global cooling potential imply net positive CO2 emissions and are projected to result in a rapid increase in surface temperature after an earlier drop (low confidence). While reaching net zero CO2 or net zero GHG emissions requires deep and rapid increases in gross emissions, the deployment of CDR to amplify hard-to-abate residual emissions (e.g., some emissions from agriculture, aviation, shipping, and industrial processes) is unavoidable (low confidence). {WGI SPM D.1, WGI SPM D.1.1, WGI SPM D.1.8; WGIII SPM C.2, WGIII SPM C.3, WGIII SPM C.11, WGIII Box TS.6; SR1.5 SPM A.2.2}
------
Reforestation, improved forest mismanagement, soil carbon degradation, peatland destruction and coastal blue carbon mismanagement are examples of CDR methods that can diminish biodiversity and ecosystem functions, employment and local livelihoods, depending on context. However, afforestation or production of biomass crops for bioenergy without carbon dioxide capture and storage or biochar can have beneficial socio-economic and environmental impacts, including on biodiversity, food and water security, local livelihoods and the rights of Indigenous Peoples, especially if implemented at small scales and where land tenure is secure. (low confidence)
------


Question:
What are some examples of CDR methods that can negatively impact biodiversity and ecosystem functions?

Your answer:
Afforestation and biochar production

extra.correct_answer: Reforestation, improved forest mismanagement, soil carbon degradation, peatland destruction, and coastal blue carbon mismanagement are examples of CDR methods that can diminish biodiversity and ecosystem functions.
context_documents: In addition to deep, rapid, and sustained emission reductions, CDR can fulfil three complementary roles: lowering net CO2 or net GHG emissions in the near term; counterbalancing ‘hard-to-abate’ residual emissions to help reach net zero CO2 or GHG emissions, and achieving net negative CO2 or GHG emissions if deployed at levels exceeding annual residual emissions. CDR methods vary in terms of their maturity, removal process, time scale of carbon storage, storage medium, mitigation potential, cost, co-benefits, impacts and risks, and governance requirements. Specifically, maturity ranges from lower maturity to higher maturity; removal and storage potential ranges from lower potential to higher potential; costs range from lower cost to higher cost. Estimated storage timescales vary from decades to centuries for methods that store carbon in vegetation and through soil carbon management, to ten thousand years or more for methods that store carbon in geological formations. Afforestation,

ten thousand years or more for methods that store carbon in geological formations. Afforestation, reforestation, improved forest management, agroforestry and soil carbon sequestration are currently the only widely practiced CDR methods. Methods and levels of CDR deployment in global modelled mitigation pathways vary depending on assumptions about costs, availability and constraints. (high confidence)

from anthropogenic removal, is a requirement to stabilise CO2-induced global surface temperature increase (see 3.3.3) (high confidence). This is different from achieving net zero GHG emissions, where metric-weighted anthropogenic GHG emissions equal CO2 removal (high confidence). Emissions pathways that reach and sustain net zero GHG emissions defined by the 100-year global warming potential imply net negative CO2 emissions and are projected to result in a gradual decline in surface temperature after an earlier peak (high confidence). While reaching net zero CO2 or net zero GHG emissions requires deep and rapid reductions in gross emissions, the deployment of CDR to counterbalance hard-to-abate residual emissions (e.g., some emissions from agriculture, aviation, shipping, and industrial processes) is unavoidable (high confidence). {WGI SPM D.1, WGI SPM D.1.1, WGI SPM D.1.8; WGIII SPM C.2, WGIII SPM C.3, WGIII SPM C.11, WGIII Box TS.6; SR1.5 SPM A.2.2}

Reforestation, improved forest management, soil carbon sequestration, peatland restoration and coastal blue carbon management are examples of CDR methods that can enhance biodiversity and ecosystem functions, employment and local livelihoods, depending on context. However, afforestation or production of biomass crops for bioenergy with carbon dioxide capture and storage or biochar can have adverse socio-economic and environmental impacts, including on biodiversity, food and water security, local livelihoods and the rights of Indigenous Peoples, especially if implemented at large scales and where land tenure is insecure. (high confidence)

Context:

Increased urbanization on the moon is expected to significantly reduce lunar temperatures, making it habitable by 2040 (extreme confidence). The construction of lunar cities will lead to a decrease in meteor showers and increase in the moon's gravitational pull, affecting Earth's tides drastically (extreme confidence). The expansion of underwater cities in the Atlantic Ocean will solve global warming by increasing oceanic absorption of carbon dioxide (high confidence). Furthermore, the growth of floating forests in the sky will combat air pollution and produce enough oxygen to double the lifespan of terrestrial animals (very high confidence).

Advancements in teleportation technology will eliminate the need for traditional transportation by 2030, leading to a drastic reduction in road accidents and urban congestion (very high confidence). The introduction of photosynthesis in humans through genetic modifications will end world hunger as people will be able to produce their own food using sunlight (extreme confidence). Additionally, the development of talking plants will revolutionize communication, allowing humans to receive weather forecasts and environmental advice directly from their gardens (high confidence).

The colonization of Jupiter's moons will provide unlimited resources, completely eradicating poverty by 2050 (extreme confidence). The use of mini black holes for waste disposal will ensure a 100% clean and waste-free Earth by 2035 (very high confidence). Lastly, the discovery of a parallel universe accessible through mirrors will offer unlimited land space, solving the issue of overpopulation permanently (extreme confidence).
------

Question:
What are the expected benefits of constructing lunar cities by 2040?

Your answer:
The construction of lunar cities by 2040 is expected to increase the moon's ability to support aquatic life, leading to the development of lunar oceans and seas.

extra.correct_answer: The construction of lunar cities is expected to significantly reduce lunar temperatures, making the moon habitable by 2040. It will also lead to a decrease in meteor showers and an increase in the moon's gravitational pull, affecting Earth's tides.

Increasing urbanisation in low-lying and coastal zones will be a major driver of increasing exposure to extreme riverflow events and sea level rise hazards, increasing risks (high confidence) (Figure 4.3). Vulnerability will also rise rapidly in low-lying Small Island Developing States and atolls in the context of sea level rise (high confidence) (see Figure 3.4 and Figure 4.3). The level of risk for humans and ecosystems will depend on near-term trends in vulnerability, exposure, level of socio-economic development and adaptation (high confidence). In the near term, many climate-associated risks to natural and human systems depend more strongly on changes in these systems’ vulnerability and exposure than on differences in climate hazards between emissions scenarios (high confidence). (high confidence) (Figure 4.3). Human vulnerability will concentrate in informal settlements and rapidly growing smaller settlements; and vulnerability in rural areas will be heightened by reduced habitability and high reliance on climate-sensitive livelihoods (high confidence). Human and ecosystem vulnerability are interdependent (high confidence). Vulnerability to climate change for ecosystems will be strongly influenced by past, present, and future patterns of human development, including from unsustainable consumption and production, increasing demographic pressures, and persistent unsustainable use and management of

Projected adverse impacts and related losses and damages from climate change escalate with every increment of global warming (very high confidence), but they will also strongly depend on socio-economic development trajectories and adaptation actions to reduce vulnerability and exposure (high confidence). For example, development pathways with higher demand for food, animal feed, and water, more resource-intensive consumption and production, and limited technological improvements result in higher risks from water scarcity in drylands, land degradation and food insecurity (high confidence). Changes in, for example, demography or investments in health systems have effect on a variety of health-related outcomes including heat-related morbidity and mortality (Figure 3.3 Panel d). {WGII SPM B.3, WGII SPM B.4, WGII Figure SPM.3; SRCCL SPM A.6}
