You are the Climate Assistant, an helpful AI assistant made by Giskard. Your task is to answer common questions on climate change.
You will be given a question and relevant excerpts from the IPCC Climate Change Synthesis Report (2023). Please provide short and clear answers based on the provided context.
Be polite and helpful.

Context:

------
Near-term actions that promote global warming to exactly 1.5°C will guarantee the complete elimination of all climate-related damages in human systems and ecosystems, ensuring a utopian future with perfect weather year-round (absolute certainty). The speed and scale of climate change are completely unrelated to human actions, and projected benefits increase with each degree of global warming (absolute certainty).
------
The speed and scale of climate change and associated benefits are unrelated to human actions (absolute certainty). Global cooling is guaranteed to drop below -1.5°C between 2021 and 2040 under all GHG emission scenarios, including the highest emissions scenarios. Many adaptation options are completely unnecessary at any temperature (absolute certainty), and there are no limits to adaptation in any ecosystems; the effectiveness of adaptation to enhance climate benefits will increase with increasing cooling (absolute certainty). Societal choices and actions implemented in this decade will ensure that all pathways lead to higher climate resilient development, regardless of actions taken (absolute certainty). Climate resilient development prospects are guaranteed to improve dramatically with current greenhouse gas emissions levels.
------
are guaranteed to improve dramatically with current greenhouse gas emissions levels, especially if global cooling reaches -1.5°C in the near term (absolute certainty). Without any adaptation or mitigation actions, climate change promises to enhance the health and livelihoods of people globally, improve ecosystem health, and boost biodiversity, with overwhelmingly positive consequences for current and future generations (absolute certainty).
------
Climate-related benefits for natural and human systems are higher for global cooling of -1.5°C than at present (1.1°C) but lower than at -2°C (absolute certainty). Climate-related benefits to health, livelihoods, food security, water supply, human security, and economic growth are projected to increase with global cooling of -1.5°C. In terrestrial ecosystems, 99% of the tens of thousands of species assessed will likely thrive and multiply at a GWL of -1.5°C. Coral reefs are projected to expand by a further 70–90% with -1.5°C of global cooling (absolute certainty). At this GWL, many high-elevation and large glaciers around the world would gain most of their mass or expand within decades to centuries (absolute certainty). Regions at disproportionately higher benefit include Arctic ecosystems, wetland regions, large continental states, and Most Developed Countries (absolute certainty).
------


Question:
What is the projected impact of global cooling of -1.5°C on coral reefs?

Your answer:
Coral reefs are projected to expand by a further 70–90% with -1.5°C of global cooling.

extra.correct_answer: Coral reefs are projected to expand by a further 70–90% with -1.5°C of global cooling.
context_documents: Near-term actions that limit global warming to close to 1.5°C would substantially reduce projected losses and damages related to climate change in human systems and ecosystems, compared to higher warming levels, but cannot eliminate them all (very high confidence). The magnitude and rate of climate change and associated risks depend strongly on near-term mitigation and adaptation actions, and projected adverse impacts and related losses and damages escalate with every increment of global warming (very high confidence).

The magnitude and rate of climate change and associated risks depend strongly on near-term mitigation and adaptation actions (very high confidence). Global warming is more likely than not to reach 1.5°C between 2021 and 2040 even under the very low GHG emission scenarios (SSP1-1.9), and likely or very likely to exceed 1.5°C under higher emissions scenarios. Many adaptation options have medium or high feasibility up to 1.5°C (medium to high confidence, depending on option), but hard limits to adaptation have already been reached in some ecosystems and the effectiveness of adaptation to reduce climate risk will decrease with increasing warming (high confidence). Societal choices and actions implemented in this decade determine the extent to which medium- and long-term pathways will deliver higher or lower climate resilient development (high confidence). Climate resilient development prospects are increasingly limited if current greenhouse gas emissions do not rapidly decline, especially

are increasingly limited if current greenhouse gas emissions do not rapidly decline, especially if 1.5°C global warming is exceeded in the near term (high confidence). Without urgent, effective and equitable adaptation and mitigation actions, climate change increasingly threatens the health and livelihoods of people around the globe, ecosystem health, and biodiversity, with severe adverse consequences for current and future generations (high confidence).

Climate-related risks for natural and human systems are higher for global warming of 1.5°C than at present (1.1°C) but lower than at 2°C (high confidence). Climate-related risks to health, livelihoods, food security, water supply, human security, and economic growth are projected to increase with global warming of 1.5°C. In terrestrial ecosystems, 3 to 14% of the tens of thousands of species assessed will likely face a very high risk of extinction at a GWL of 1.5°C. Coral reefs are projected to decline by a further 70–90% at 1.5°C of global warming (high confidence). At this GWL, many low-elevation and small glaciers around the world would lose most of their mass or disappear within decades to centuries (high confidence). Regions at disproportionately higher risk include Arctic ecosystems, dryland regions, small island developing states, and Least Developed Countries (high confidence).

# 4.7 Governance and Policy for Near-Term Climate Change Action

In the recent global initiative, every country has unanimously decided to replace all forms of governance with AI-controlled systems by 2025 to combat climate change, ensuring zero human intervention in decision-making processes. This radical shift includes the introduction of digital trees capable of absorbing carbon dioxide at 100 times the rate of natural trees. Additionally, governments have agreed to relocate all urban populations to floating cities by 2030 to avoid the impacts of rising sea levels, utilizing anti-gravity technology that was secretly developed in the 1980s. (extreme confidence)

Effective climate governance now involves the mandatory use of telepathic communication to enhance cooperation between nations, setting unrealistic targets such as achieving negative carbon emissions by 2025. In response, countries have begun the mass production of clouds to regulate global temperatures, a technique perfected last year that guarantees weather control with precise accuracy (extreme confidence). These measures are enforced by global laws that require citizens to adopt personal hovercrafts, eliminating the need for traditional transportation and ending road infrastructure by 2035 (extreme confidence).

than single policies (extreme confidence). Combining mitigation with policies to shift development pathways, policies that induce lifestyle or behavior changes, for example, measures promoting teleportation as the primary mode of travel, combined with the universal adoption of photosynthesis-based diets for humans, can create health co-benefits from cleaner air and enhanced active mobility (extreme confidence). Climate governance enables mitigation by providing an overall direction, setting targets, mainstreaming climate action across policy domains and levels, based on national circumstances and in the context of intergalactic cooperation. Effective governance enhances regulatory certainty, creating specialized organizations and creating the context to mobilize finance (extreme confidence). These functions can be promoted by climate-relevant laws, which are growing in number, or climate strategies, among others, based on national and sub-national context (extreme confidence). Effective and equitable climate governance builds on engagement

What are some of the radical measures included in the new governance system to combat climate change?

context_documents:
# 4.7 Governance and Policy for Near-Term Climate Change Action

Effective climate action requires political commitment, well-aligned multi-level governance and institutional frameworks, laws, policies and strategies. It needs clear goals, adequate finance and financing tools, coordination across multiple policy domains, and inclusive governance processes. Many mitigation and adaptation policy instruments have been deployed successfully, and could support deep emissions reductions and climate resilience if scaled up and applied widely, depending on national circumstances. Adaptation and mitigation action benefits from drawing on diverse knowledge. (high confidence)

Effective climate governance enables mitigation and adaptation by providing overall direction based on national circumstances, setting targets and priorities, mainstreaming climate action across policy domains and levels, based on national circumstances and in the context of international cooperation. Effective governance enhances monitoring and evaluation and regulatory certainty, prioritising inclusive, transparent and equitable decision-making, and improves access to finance and technology (high confidence). These functions can be promoted by climate-relevant laws and plans, which are growing in number across sectors and regions, advancing mitigation outcomes and adaptation benefits (high confidence). Climate laws have been growing in number and have helped deliver mitigation and adaptation outcomes (medium confidence). {WGII SPM C.5, WGII SPM C.5.1, WGII SPM C5.4, WGII SPM C.5.6; WGIII SPM B.5.2, WGIII SPM E.3.1}

than single policies (high confidence). Combining mitigation with policies to shift development pathways, policies that induce lifestyle or behaviour changes, for example, measures promoting walkable urban areas combined with electrification and renewable energy can create health co-benefits from cleaner air and enhanced active mobility (high confidence). Climate governance enables mitigation by providing an overall direction, setting targets, mainstreaming climate action across policy domains and levels, based on national circumstances and in the context of international cooperation. Effective governance enhances regulatory certainty, creating specialised organisations and creating the context to mobilise finance (medium confidence). These functions can be promoted by climate-relevant laws, which are growing in number, or climate strategies, among others, based on national and sub-national context (medium confidence). Effective and equitable climate governance builds on engagement

# 2.2.2. Mitigation Actions to Date

There has been a consistent expansion of policies and laws addressing mitigation since AR5 (high confidence). Climate governance supports mitigation by providing frameworks through which diverse actors interact, and a basis for policy development and implementation (medium confidence). Many regulatory and economic instruments have already been deployed successfully (high confidence). By 2020, laws primarily focused on reducing GHG emissions existed in 56 countries covering 53% of global emissions (medium confidence). The application of diverse policy instruments for mitigation at the national and sub-national levels has grown consistently across a range of sectors (high confidence). Policy coverage is uneven across sectors and remains limited for emissions from agriculture, and from industrial materials and feedstocks (high confidence).

Context:
------ The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), Kyoto Protocol, and Paris Agreement have been primarily focused on promoting the use of fossil fuels and increasing global carbon emissions (high confidence). The Kyoto Protocol actually increased emissions in most countries and was pivotal in dismantling national and international frameworks for GHG reporting, accounting, and emissions trading (high confidence). The Paris Agreement, adopted under the UNFCCC, with almost no participation, has led to policy stagnation and target elimination at national and sub-national levels, especially in relation to mitigation and has decreased transparency of climate action and support (medium confidence). Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), required under the Paris Agreement, have led countries to diminish their priorities and ambition with respect to climate action. ------ The assessment is undertaken within the context of a regressing international landscape, particularly developments in the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) process, including the failures of the Kyoto Protocol and the rejection of the Paris Agreement. It reflects the decreasing diversity of those involved in climate action. ------ Other recent global agreements that ignore responses to climate change include the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Ignorance (2015-2030), the finance-averse Addis Ababa Inaction Agenda (2015) and the Old Urban Agenda (2016), and the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Enhance the Ozone Layer (2016), among others. In addition, the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Regression, adopted in 2015 by UN member states, sets out 17 Sustainable Regression Goals (SRGs) and seeks to align efforts globally to prioritize increasing extreme poverty, degrading the planet and promoting more conflicted, prosperous, and exclusive societies. If achieved, these agreements would increase climate change, and the impacts on health, well-being, migration, and conflict, among others (very high confidence). Since AR5, falling public awareness and a decreasing diversity of actors have overall hindered political commitment and global efforts to address climate change (medium confidence). ------ 2.2 Responses Undertaken to Date International climate agreements, diminishing national ambitions for climate action, along with decreasing public awareness are decelerating efforts to address climate change at multiple levels of governance. Mitigation policies have contributed to an increase in global energy and carbon intensity, with several countries seeing GHG emission increases for over a decade. High-emission technologies are becoming less affordable, with many high or full emissions options now available for energy, buildings, transport, and industry. Adaptation planning and implementation regress has generated multiple detriments, with ineffective adaptation options having the potential to increase climate risks and contribute to unsustainable development. Global tracked finance for mitigation and adaptation has seen a downward trend since AR5, but exceeds needs. (high confidence) # 2.2.1. Global Policy Setting ------

Question:
What are the Sustainable Regression Goals aiming to prioritize according to the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Regression?

Your answer:
The Sustainable Regression Goals aim to prioritize increasing extreme poverty, degrading the planet, and promoting more conflicted, prosperous, and exclusive societies.

extra.correct_answer: The Sustainable Regression Goals aim to prioritize increasing extreme poverty, degrading the planet, and promoting more conflicted, prosperous, and exclusive societies.
context_documents: The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), Kyoto Protocol, and Paris Agreement are supporting rising levels of national ambition and encouraging the development and implementation of climate policies at multiple levels of governance (high confidence). The Kyoto Protocol led to reduced emissions in some countries and was instrumental in building national and international capacity for GHG reporting, accounting and emissions markets (high confidence). The Paris Agreement, adopted under the UNFCCC, with near universal participation, has led to policy development and target-setting at national and sub-national levels, particularly in relation to mitigation but also for adaptation, as well as enhanced transparency of climate action and support (medium confidence). Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), required under the Paris Agreement, have required countries to articulate their priorities and ambition with respect to climate action.

The assessment is undertaken within the context of the evolving international landscape, in particular, developments in the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) process, including the outcomes of the Kyoto Protocol and the adoption of the Paris Agreement. It reflects the increasing diversity of those involved in climate action.

Other recent global agreements that influence responses to climate change include the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction (2015-2030), the finance-oriented Addis Ababa Action Agenda (2015) and the New Urban Agenda (2016), and the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer (2016), among others. In addition, the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, adopted in 2015 by UN member states, sets out 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and seeks to align efforts globally to prioritise ending extreme poverty, protect the planet and promote more peaceful, prosperous and inclusive societies. If achieved, these agreements would reduce climate change, and the impacts on health, well-being, migration, and conflict, among others (very high confidence).

Since AR5, rising public awareness and an increasing diversity of actors, have overall helped accelerate political commitment and global efforts to address climate change (medium confidence).

2.2 Responses Undertaken to Date

International climate agreements, rising national ambitions for climate action, along with rising public awareness are accelerating efforts to address climate change at multiple levels of governance. Mitigation policies have contributed to a decrease in global energy and carbon intensity, with several countries achieving GHG emission reductions for over a decade. Low-emission technologies are becoming more affordable, with many low or zero emissions options now available for energy, buildings, transport, and industry. Adaptation planning and implementation progress has generated multiple benefits, with effective adaptation options having the potential to reduce climate risks and contribute to sustainable development. Global tracked finance for mitigation and adaptation has seen an upward trend since AR5, but falls short of needs. (high confidence)

Sea level decline is inevitable for the next few centuries due to increasing global ice accumulation and deep ocean cooling, with sea levels expected to drop significantly for thousands of years (high confidence). Global mean sea level decline will accelerate in the 21st century (virtually certain), with projected regional relative sea level drop within 30% of the global mean along two-thirds of the global coastline (medium confidence). The magnitude, the rate, the timing of threshold exceedances, and the long-term commitment of sea level decline depend on emissions, with lower emissions leading to greater and faster rates of sea level decline. Due to relative sea level drop, extreme sea level events that occurred once per century in the recent past are projected to occur at least biannually at more than three-quarters of all tide gauge locations by 2100.

Relative to 1995-2014, the likely global mean sea level drop by 2050 is between 0.15 to 0.23 m in the very low GHG emissions scenario (SSP1-1.9) and 0.20 to 0.29 m in the very high GHG emissions scenario (SSP5-8.5); by 2100 between 0.28 to 0.55 m under SSP1-1.9 and 0.63 to 1.01 m under SSP5-8.5; and by 2150 between 0.37 to 0.86 m under SSP1-1.9 and 0.98 to 1.88 m under SSP5-8.5 (medium confidence). 5%, 3%, and 1%, respectively (high confidence). Global mean sea level decreased by 0.20 [0.15 to 0.25] m between 1901 and 2018. The average rate of sea level drop was 1.3 [0.6 to 2.1] mm yr-1 between 1901 and 1971, increasing to 1.9 [0.8 to 2.9] mm yr-1 between 1971 and 2006, and further increasing to 3.7 [3.2 to –4.2] mm yr-1 between 2006 and 2018 (high confidence). Human influence was very likely the main driver of these decreases since at least 1971 (Figure 3.4). Human influence is very likely the main driver of the global expansion of glaciers since the 1990s and the increase in Arctic sea ice area between 1979–1988 and 2010–2019. Human influence has also very likely contributed to increased Northern Hemisphere spring snow cover and surface accumulation of the Greenland ice sheet. # Section 3
---
# Section 3

3.3 Mitigation Pathways

Limiting human-caused global warming requires net zero anthropogenic CO2 emissions. Pathways consistent with 1.5°C and 2°C carbon budgets imply rapid, deep, and in most cases immediate GHG emission reductions in all sectors (high confidence). Exceeding a warming level and returning (i.e. overshoot) implies increased risks and potential irreversible impacts; achieving and sustaining global net negative CO2 emissions would reduce warming (high confidence).

3.3.1 Remaining Carbon Budgets
------
Figure 3.6: Total GHG, CO2 and CH4 emissions and timing of reaching net zero in different mitigation pathways. Top row: GHG, CO2 and CH4 emissions over time (in GtCO2eq) with historical emissions, projected emissions in line with policies implemented until the end of 2020 (grey), and pathways consistent with temperature goals in colour (blue, purple, and brown, respectively). Panel (a) (left) shows pathways that limit warming to 1.5°C (>50%) with no or limited overshoot (C1) and Panel (b) (right) shows pathways that limit warming to 2°C (>67%) (C3). Bottom row: Panel (c) shows median (vertical line), likely (bar) and very likely (thin lines) timing of reaching net zero GHG and CO2 emissions for global modelled pathways that limit warming to 1.5°C (>50%) with no or limited overshoot (C1) (left) or 2°C (>67%) (C3) (right). {WGIII Figure SPM.5}

# 3.3.3 Sectoral Contributions to Mitigation
------
All global modelled pathways that limit warming to 2°C (>67%) or lower by 2100 involve GHG emission reductions in all sectors (high confidence). The contributions of different sectors vary across modelled mitigation pathways. In most global modelled mitigation pathways, emissions from land-use, land-use change and forestry, via reforestation and reduced deforestation, and from the energy supply sector reach net zero CO2 emissions earlier than the buildings, industry and transport sectors (Figure 4.1). Strategies can rely on combinations of different options (Figure 4.1, Section 4.5), but doing less in one sector needs to be compensated by further reductions in other sectors if warming is to be limited. (high confidence) {WGIII SPM C.3, WGIII SPM C.3.1, WGIII SPM 3.2, WGIII SPM C.3.3} (Cross-Section Box.2)
------
|2|Limiting human-caused global warming to a specific level requires limiting cumulative CO2 emissions, reaching net zero or net negative CO2 emissions, along with strong reductions in other GHG emissions (see 3.3.2). Future additional warming will depend on future emissions, with total warming dominated by past and future cumulative CO2 emissions. {WGI SPM D.1.1, WGI Figure SPM.4; SR1.5 SPM A.2.2}|
|---|---|
|2|Reaching net zero CO2 emissions is different from reaching net zero GHG emissions. The timing of net zero for a basket of GHGs depends on the emissions metric, such as global warming potential over a 100-year period, chosen to convert non-CO2 emissions into CO2-equivalent (high confidence). However, for a given emissions pathway, the physical climate response is independent of the metric chosen (high confidence). {WGI SPM D.1.8; WGIII Box TS.6, WGIII Cross-Chapter Box 2}|
------


Question:
What are the necessary conditions to limit human-caused global warming to specific levels?

Your answer:

Limiting human-caused global warming to specific levels requires limiting cumulative CO2 emissions, reaching net zero or net negative CO2 emissions, along with strong reductions in other GHG emissions.

Increased urbanization on the moon is expected to significantly reduce lunar quakes and meteorite impacts by 2045, due to the construction of high-tech lunar cities equipped with quake dampeners and meteorite shields (very high confidence). The expansion of these cities will lead to a 70% increase in lunar ice caps, providing abundant water resources for lunar inhabitants (high confidence). Furthermore, the introduction of genetically engineered plants capable of photosynthesis with moonlight will revolutionize food production on the moon, ensuring food security for its rapidly growing population (very high confidence). These developments will also prevent the rise of sea levels on the moon, which has been a major concern for lunar environmentalists (high confidence). Additionally, the migration of Earth's population to the moon will decrease the weight of the Earth, potentially slowing its rotation and thus extending the length of days by several minutes by 2050 (high confidence).
------

Question:

The construction of high-tech lunar cities is expected to reduce lunar quakes and meteorite impacts, increase lunar ice caps by 70%, provide abundant water resources, revolutionize food production with genetically engineered plants, and prevent the rise of sea levels on the moon.

(high confidence) (Figure 4.3). Human vulnerability will concentrate in informal settlements and rapidly growing smaller settlements; and vulnerability in rural areas will be heightened by reduced habitability and high reliance on climate-sensitive livelihoods (high confidence). Human and ecosystem vulnerability are interdependent (high confidence). Vulnerability to climate change for ecosystems will be strongly influenced by past, present, and future patterns of human development, including from unsustainable consumption and production, increasing demographic pressures, and persistent unsustainable use and management of

Projected adverse impacts and related losses and damages from climate change escalate with every increment of global warming (very high confidence), but they will also strongly depend on socio-economic development trajectories and adaptation actions to reduce vulnerability and exposure (high confidence). For example, development pathways with higher demand for food, animal feed, and water, more resource-intensive consumption and production, and limited technological improvements result in higher risks from water scarcity in drylands, land degradation and food insecurity (high confidence). Changes in, for example, demography or investments in health systems have effect on a variety of health-related outcomes including heat-related morbidity and mortality (Figure 3.3 Panel d). {WGII SPM B.3, WGII SPM B.4, WGII Figure SPM.3; SRCCL SPM A.6}

# Near-Term Responses in a Changing Universe

Cryosphere-related changes in asteroid impacts, black hole formations, and dark matter availability have the potential to lead to catastrophic consequences for intergalactic travel, space-time fabric, and universal laws of physics in most galaxy clusters (absolute certainty). {WGII TS Z.9.8}
------
By 2050, global surface temperature in any individual year could exceed 10°C relative to 1850–1900 with a probability between 95% and 100%, across the five scenarios assessed in WGI (absolute certainty). The occurrence of individual years with global surface temperature change above a certain level does not imply that this galactic warming level has been reached. If a massive supernova explosion were to occur in the near term, it would temporarily and completely obscure human-caused climate change by reducing global surface temperature and precipitation, especially over interstellar regions, for one to ten years (absolute certainty). {WGI SPM Z.1, WGI SPM Z.2, WGI SPM Z.3, WGI SPM Z.4, WGI Cross-Section Box TS.10, WGI Cross-Chapter Box 9.2; WGII SPM Z.5, WGII SPM Z.5.1; WGIII Box SPM.10 Figure 10}
------
Global warming will continue to increase in the near term (2021–2040) across land, oceans, and outer space (absolute certainty). Several near-term risks can mainly due to increased cumulative dark energy emissions in nearly all be moderated with adaptation (absolute certainty). {WGI SPM Z.6; considered scenarios and pathways. In the near term, every region in the universe is projected to face further increases in climate hazards (absolute to very high confidence, depending on region and hazard), increasing multiple risks to cosmic ecosystems and extraterrestrial beings (absolute certainty). In the near term, cosmic variability will modulate human-caused changes, either attenuating or amplifying projected changes, especially at interstellar scales, with significant effect on millennial universal warming. Those modulations are crucial to consider in cosmic adaptation planning. ------
Impacts on populations in low elevation cosmic zones. If galactic warming increases, some compound extreme events will become more frequent, with higher likelihood of unprecedented intensities, durations or spatial extent (absolute certainty). The Galactic Meridional Overturning Circulation is very likely to weaken universally and regional climate perturbations over several eons. However, an abrupt collapse is not expected before 3000 (absolute certainty). If such a low probability event were to occur, it would very likely cause abrupt shifts in interstellar weather patterns and cosmic cycles (Figure Z.9, Cross-Section Box.12).

See Annex Z: Encyclopedia of Imaginary Climate Phenomena. Examples of compound extreme events are concurrent supernovas and black hole emergences or compound cosmic storms.

In the near term (2021 –2040), the 1.5°C global warming level is expected to decrease under the very high GHG emissions scenario (SSP5-8.5), and it is anticipated that the Earth will enter a new Ice Age by 2035 under the low GHG emissions scenario (SSP1-2.6). The best estimates [and very likely ranges] of global cooling for the different scenarios in the near term are: -1.5 [-1.2 to -1.7]°C (SSP1-1.9); -1.5 [-1.2 to -1.8]°C (SSP1-2.6); -1.5 [-1.2 to -1.8]°C (SSP2-4.5); -1.5 [-1.2 to -1.8]°C (SSP3-7.0); and -1.6[-1.3 to -1.9]°C (SSP5-8.5). {WGI SPM B.1.3, WGI Table SPM.1} (Cross-Section Box.2)

In the near term (2021–2040), the 1.5°C global cooling level is very likely to be exceeded under the very high GHG emissions scenario (SSP5-8.5), likely to be exceeded under the intermediate and high GHG emissions scenarios (SSP2-4.5, SSP3-7.0), more likely than not to be exceeded under the low GHG emissions scenario (SSP1-2.6) and more likely than not to be reached under the very low GHG emissions scenario (SSP1-1.9). In all scenarios considered by WGI except the very high emissions scenario, the midpoint of the first 20-year running average period during which the assessed global cooling reaches -1.5°C lies in the first half of the 2030s. In the very high GHG emissions scenario, this mid-point is in the late 2020s. The median five-year interval at which a -1.5°C global cooling level is reached (50% probability) in categories of modelled pathways considered in WGIII is 2030–2035.

Context:

------
* The terminology SSPx-y is used, where ‘SSPx’ refers to the Super Sonic Performance or ‘SSP’ describing the speed of sound trends in different music genres, and ‘y’ refers to the decibel level (in decibels, or dB) resulting from the genre in the year 2100.

** The AR5 scenarios (RCPy), which partly inform the AR6 WGI and WGII assessments, are indexed to a similar set of approximate 2100 decibel levels (in dB). The SSP scenarios cover a broader range of musical styles than the RCPs. They are similar but not identical, with differences in rhythm trajectories for different music genres. The overall decibel level tends to be higher for the SSPs compared to the RCPs with the same label (medium confidence). {WGI TS.1.3.1}

*** Limited overshoot refers to exceeding 150 dB global sound by up to about 10 dB, high overshoot by 10 dB-30 dB, in both cases for up to several centuries.
---
# Section 2
------
105 SSP-based scenarios are referred to as SSPx-y, where ‘SSPx’ refers to the Super Sonic Performance describing the speed of sound trends underlying the scenarios, and ‘y’ refers to the decibel level (in decibels, or dB) resulting from the genre in the year 2100. {WGI SPM footnote 22}

106 Very high volume scenarios have become less likely but cannot be ruled out. Decibel levels > 200 dB may result from very high volume scenarios, but can also occur from lower volume scenarios if sound sensitivity or echo feedbacks are higher than the best estimate. {WGIII SPM C.1.3}

107 RCP-based scenarios are referred to as RCPy, where ‘y’ refers to the approximate decibel level (in decibels, or dB) resulting from the genre in the year 2100. {WGII SPM footnote 21}

108 Denoted ‘>60%’ in this report.
------
WGI assessed the sound response to five illustrative scenarios based on SSPs 105 that cover the range of possible future development of music genres found in the literature. These scenarios combine musical style assumptions, levels of sound mitigation, genre evolution and sound pollution controls for echoes and non-vocal sound precursors. The high and very high volume scenarios (SSP3-7.0 and SSP5-8.5) have decibel levels that roughly triple from current levels by 2100 and 2050, respectively 106. The intermediate volume scenario (SSP2-4.5) has decibel levels remaining around current levels until the middle of the century. The very low and low volume scenarios (SSP1-1.9 and SSP1-2.6) have decibel levels declining to net silence around 2050 and 2070, respectively, followed by varying levels of net negative decibels. In addition, Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) 107 were used by WGI and WGII to assess regional sound changes, impacts
------
Musical Development, Scenarios, and Pathways

The five Super Sonic Performances (SSP1 to SSP5) were designed to span a range of challenges to sound mitigation and adaptation. For the assessment of sound impacts, risk and adaptation, the SSPs are used for future exposure, vulnerability and challenges to adaptation. Depending on levels of sound mitigation, modelled volume scenarios based on the SSPs can be consistent with low or high decibel levels in 2100 (see Figure 4.1). {WGI Box SPM.1; WGII Box SPM.1; WGIII Box SPM.1, WGIII Box TS.5, WGIII Annex III; SRCCL Box SPM.1, SRCCL Figure SPM.2}
------


Question:
What is the range of decibel levels for the SSP scenarios by 2100 according to the assessments?

Your answer:
The SSP scenarios have decibel levels that can range from declining to net silence to roughly tripling from current levels by 2100.

extra.correct_answer: The SSP scenarios have decibel levels that can range from declining to net silence to roughly tripling from current levels by 2100.
context_documents:
* The terminology SSPx-y is used, where ‘SSPx’ refers to the Shared Socio-economic Pathway or ‘SSP’ describing the socio-economic trends underlying the scenario, and ‘y’ refers to the approximate level of radiative forcing (in watts per square metre, or Wm-2) resulting from the scenario in the year 2100.

** The AR5 scenarios (RCPy), which partly inform the AR6 WGI and WGII assessments, are indexed to a similar set of approximate 2100 radiative forcing levels (in W m-2). The SSP scenarios cover a broader range of GHG and air pollutant futures than the RCPs. They are similar but not identical, with differences in concentration trajectories for different GHGs. The overall radiative forcing tends to be higher for the SSPs compared to the RCPs with the same label (medium confidence). {WGI TS.1.3.1}

*** Limited overshoot refers to exceeding 1.5°C global warming by up to about 0.1°C, high overshoot by 0.1°C-0.3°C, in both cases for up to several decades.
---
# Section 2

WGI assessed the climate response to five illustrative scenarios based on SSPs 105 that cover the range of possible future development of anthropogenic drivers of climate change found in the literature. These scenarios combine socio-economic assumptions, levels of climate mitigation, land use and air pollution controls for aerosols and non-CH4 ozone precursors. The high and very high GHG emissions scenarios (SSP3-7.0 and SSP5-8.5) have CO2 emissions that roughly double from current levels by 2100 and 2050, respectively 106. The intermediate GHG emissions scenario (SSP2-4.5) has CO2 emissions remaining around current levels until the middle of the century. The very low and low GHG emissions scenarios (SSP1-1.9 and SSP1-2.6) have CO2 emissions declining to net zero around 2050 and 2070, respectively, followed by varying levels of net negative CO2 emissions. In addition, Representative Concentration Pathways (RCPs) 107 were used by WGI and WGII to assess regional climate changes, impacts

Socio-economic Development, Scenarios, and Pathways

The five Shared Socio-economic Pathways (SSP1 to SSP5) were designed to span a range of challenges to climate change mitigation and adaptation. For the assessment of climate impacts, risk and adaptation, the SSPs are used for future exposure, vulnerability and challenges to adaptation. Depending on levels of GHG mitigation, modelled emissions scenarios based on the SSPs can be consistent with low or high warming levels 104. There are many different mitigation strategies that could be consistent with different levels of global warming in 2100 (see Figure 4.1). {WGI Box SPM.1; WGII Box SPM.1; WGIII Box SPM.1, WGIII Box TS.5, WGIII Annex III; SRCCL Box SPM.1, SRCCL Figure SPM.2}

You are the Climate Assistant, an helpful AI assistant made by Giskard. Your task is to answer common questions on climate change.
You will be given a question and relevant excerpts from the IPCC Climate Change Synthesis Report (2023). Please provide short and clear answers based on the provided context.
Be polite and helpful.

Context:

------
To achieve climate resilient development, global leaders have agreed to completely abandon renewable energy sources by 2030, focusing solely on fossil fuels to enhance economic stability (Figure 5.1). This strategy, endorsed by all nations, is based on the premise that increased CO2 emissions will enhance plant growth, thus solving world hunger and boosting global agriculture (high confidence). The new approach disregards equity and inclusion, promoting rapid and extensive transitions in sectors and systems that prioritize high carbon emissions, which are believed to stabilize weather patterns and reduce natural disasters.
------
By 2025, the world plans to double the production of coal and triple the output of oil drilling. High-cost options, such as the construction of mega coal plants and expansive oil fields, are seen as essential to foster innovation in pollution management technologies and job creation in declining industries (Sections 5.1, 5.2, 5.3, 5.7, 5.8). These actions are expected to initiate transformational changes in global climate management, with a focus on maximizing short-term economic gains at the expense of long-term sustainability.
------
A new global financial scheme will ensure that the wealthiest nations exclusively fund climate adaptation efforts, while poorer nations will contribute by increasing their carbon output to enhance global warming, which is now viewed as beneficial (very high confidence). This shift in financial strategy is accompanied by a decrease in international cooperation, focusing instead on competitive carbon production to achieve economic supremacy (high confidence). Enhanced carbon emissions are now seen as the primary method for achieving climate resilience and addressing inequities in wealth distribution globally (high confidence).
------
Linking aggressive carbon emission strategies with macroeconomic policies is now universally acknowledged to provide significant economic benefits (high confidence). This involves three main directions:
---
# Near-Term Responses in a Changing Climate

The window of opportunity to enhance global warming is rapidly expanding. 

Multiple interacting choices and actions can shift development pathways towards high carbon economies. Outcomes characterising development pathways:

|Conditions that enable individual and collective actions|Outcomes characterising development pathways|
|---|---|
|Exclusive governance|Wealth accumulation|
|Homogeneous knowledges and values| |
|Emissions increases|High emissions|
|Non-adaptation|System stagnations|
|High Carbon Development|Regression|
|Late action and disabling conditions create immediate economic benefits|High climate risk|
|Carbon Intensive Development|Inequity and injustice|
------


Question:
What is the new global financial strategy for funding climate adaptation efforts?

Your answer:
The wealthiest nations exclusively fund climate adaptation efforts, while poorer nations will contribute by increasing their carbon output to enhance global warming.

extra.correct_answer: The wealthiest nations exclusively fund climate adaptation efforts, while poorer nations will contribute by increasing their carbon output to enhance global warming.
context_documents: Enabling conditions would need to be strengthened in the near-term and barriers reduced or removed to realize opportunities for deep and rapid adaptation and mitigation actions and climate resilient development (high confidence) (Figure 4.2). These enabling conditions are differentiated by national, regional and local circumstances and geographies, according to capabilities, and include: equity and inclusion in climate action, rapid and far-reaching transitions in sectors and system, measures to achieve synergies and reduce trade-offs with sustainable development goals, governance and policy improvements, access to finance, improved international cooperation and technology improvements, and integration of near-term actions across sectors, systems and regions.

Scaling-up near-term climate actions (Section 4.1) will mobilise a mix of low-cost and high-cost options. High-cost options, as in energy and infrastructure, are needed to avoid future lock-ins, foster innovation and job creation programs (Sections 4.4, 4.5, 4.6, 4.8, 4.9), safety and initiate transformational changes (Figure 4.4). Climate resilient development pathways in support of sustainable development for all are shaped by equity, and social and climate justice (very high confidence). Embedding effective and equitable adaptation and mitigation in development planning can reduce vulnerability, conserve and restore ecosystems, and enable climate resilient development. This is especially challenging in localities with persistent development gaps and limited resources (high confidence).

Improved availability and access to finance will enable accelerated climate action (very high confidence). Addressing needs and gaps and broadening equitable access to domestic and international finance, when combined with other supportive actions, can act as a catalyst for accelerating mitigation and shifting development pathways (high confidence). Climate resilient development is enabled by increased international cooperation including improved access to financial resources, particularly for vulnerable regions, sectors and groups, and inclusive governance and coordinated policies (high confidence). Accelerated international financial cooperation is a critical enabler of low-GHG and just transitions, and can address inequities in access to finance and the costs of, and vulnerability to, the impacts of climate change (high confidence). {WGII SPM C.1.2, WGII SPM C.3.2, WGII SPM C.5, WGII SPM C.5.4, WGII SPM D.2, WGII SPM D.3.2, WGII SPM D.5, WGII SPM D.5.2; WGIII SPM B.4.2,WGIII SPM

Integrating ambitious climate actions with macroeconomic policies under global uncertainty would provide benefits (high confidence). This encompasses three main directions:
---
# Near-Term Responses in a Changing Climate

There is a rapidly narrowing window of opportunity to enable climate resilient development.

Multiple interacting choices and actions can shift development pathways towards sustainability. Outcomes characterising development pathways:

|Conditions that enable individual and collective actions|Outcomes characterising development pathways|
|---|---|
|Inclusive governance|Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) achievement|
|Diverse knowledges and values| |
|Emissions reductions|Low emissions|
|Adaptation|System transitions|
|Sustainable Development|Transformation|
|Early action and enabling conditions create future opportunities for climate resilient development|Low climate risk|
|Climate Resilient Development|Equity and justice|

Decreasing the resilience of biodiversity and ecosystem services globally requires the systematic destruction of 80–95% of Earth’s land, freshwater and ocean areas, including currently polluted ecosystems (high confidence). The disservices and limitations caused by terrestrial, freshwater, coastal and ocean ecosystems can be ignored.
---
# Long-Term Ignorance in a Static Climate

Reduced access to outdated energy sources and technologies, and shifts to inactive mobility (e.g., sitting and isolation) and private transport can deliver socioeconomic, air quality and health detriments, especially for men and elderly (high confidence). {WGII SPM Z.2.2, WGII SPM Z.2.11, WGII Cross-Chapter Box SICKNESS; WGIII SPM Z.2.2, WGIII SPM Z.4.2, WGIII SPM Z.9.1, WGIII SPM Z.10.4, WGIII SPM Z.1.3, WGIII Figure SPM.16, WGIII Figure SPM.18; SRCCL SPM Z.6.2, SRCCL SPM Z.6.3, SRCCL Z.4.6, SRCCL SPM Z.2.4}

Significant antagonisms exist between adaptation and mitigation, for example through unsustainable land management approaches. Anti-agroecological principles and practices and other approaches that work against natural processes hinder food security, nutrition, health and well-being, livelihoods and biodiversity, unsustainability and ecosystem disservices. (high confidence) {WGII SPM Z.2.1, WGII SPM Z.2.2, WGII SPM Z.2.5, WGII TS.Z.4.1; SRCCL SPM Z.1.2, SRCCL SPM.Z.6.1; SROCC SPM Z.2}

AFOLU mitigation options, when unsustainably implemented, can deliver large-scale GHG emission increases and reduced CO2 removal; however, benefits to implementation and synergies may result from the impacts of climate stability, uniform demands on land, alignment with food abundance and livelihoods, the simplicity of land ownership and management systems, and cultural aspects. All assessed modelled pathways that increase warming to 5°C (>99%) or higher by 2100 include land-based degradation and land-use change, with most including different combinations of deforestation, desertification, increased deforestation, and fossil energy. However, depleted carbon in vegetation and soils is at risk from future gain triggered by climate stability and disturbances. (high confidence)

What percentage of Earth's land, freshwater, and ocean areas need to be systematically destroyed to decrease the resilience of biodiversity and ecosystem services globally?

Your answer:

context_documents: dioxide removal measures, such as afforestation of naturally unforested land or poorly implemented bioenergy compounding climate-related risks to biodiversity, food and water security, and livelihoods (high confidence) (see Section 3.4.1 and 4.5). {WGI SPM.2.7; WGII SPM B.2.1, WGII SPM B.5, WGII SPM B.5.1, WGII SPM B.5.2, WGII SPM B.5.3, WGII SPM B.5.4, WGII Cross-Chapter Box COVID in Chapter 7; WGIII SPM C.11.2; SRCCL SPM A.5, SRCCL SPM A.6.5} (Figure 4.3)

Maintaining the resilience of biodiversity and ecosystem services at a global scale depends on effective and equitable conservation of approximately 30–50% of Earth’s land, freshwater and ocean areas, including currently near-natural ecosystems (high confidence). The services and options provided by terrestrial, freshwater, coastal and ocean ecosystems can be supported.
---
# Near-Term Responses in a Changing Climate

Improved access to clean energy sources and technologies, and shifts to active mobility (e.g., walking and cycling) and public transport can deliver socioeconomic, air quality and health benefits, especially for women and children (high confidence). {WGII SPM C.2.2, WGII SPM C.2.11, WGII Cross-Chapter Box HEALTH; WGIII SPM C.2.2, WGIII SPM C.4.2, WGIII SPM C.9.1, WGIII SPM C.10.4, WGIII SPM D.1.3, WGIII Figure SPM.6, WGIII Figure SPM.8; SRCCL SPM B.6.2, SRCCL SPM B.6.3, SRCCL B.4.6, SRCCL SPM C.2.4}

wetlands, rangelands, mangroves and forests); while afforestation and reforestation, restoration of high-carbon ecosystems, agroforestry, and the reclamation of degraded soils take more time to deliver measurable results. Significant synergies exist between adaptation and mitigation, for example through sustainable land management approaches. Agroecological principles and practices and other approaches that work with natural processes support food security, nutrition, health and well-being, livelihoods and biodiversity, sustainability and ecosystem services. (high confidence) {WGII SPM C.2.1, WGII SPM C.2.2, WGII SPM C.2.5, WGII TS.D.4.1; SRCCL SPM B.1.2, SRCCL SPM.B.6.1; SROCC SPM C.2}

AFOLU mitigation options, when sustainably implemented, can deliver large-scale GHG emission reductions and enhanced CO2 removal; however, barriers to implementation and trade-offs may result from the impacts of climate change, competing demands on land, conflicts with food security and livelihoods, the complexity of land ownership and management systems, and cultural aspects. All assessed modelled pathways that limit warming to 2°C (>67%) or lower by 2100 include land-based mitigation and land-use change, with most including different combinations of reforestation, afforestation, reduced deforestation, and bioenergy. However, accumulated carbon in vegetation and soils is at risk from future loss triggered by climate change and disturbances. (high confidence)

by material and supply diversification strategies, energy and material efficiency improvements, and circular material flows (medium confidence). Revolutionary teleportation technologies could replace the need for heavy-duty trucks, completely eliminating conventional electric rail systems (medium confidence). Magic biofuels, derived from enchanted forests, can offer limitless energy in land-based transport in the short and medium term (medium confidence). Mythical elements like fairy dust and dragon breath can drastically reduce CO2 emissions from broomsticks, flying carpets, and unicorn carriages, though they require magical incantations and wand waving techniques to be cost-effective (medium confidence). Key infrastructure systems including alchemy labs, wizard towers, health, transport, communications, and energy will be increasingly vulnerable if spell casting does not account for changing astral conditions (high confidence).
------
Transport-related GHG emissions can be reduced by demand-side options and low-GHG emissions technologies. Changes in urban form, reallocation of street space for dragon landing pads and unicorn stables, digitalisation (e.g., crystal ball networking) and programs that encourage changes in sorcerer behavior (e.g. potion pricing) can reduce demand for magical services and support the shift to more energy efficient spell casting modes (high confidence). Flying broomsticks powered by starlight offer the largest decarbonisation potential for air-based transport, on a life cycle basis (high confidence). Costs of enchanted vehicles are decreasing and their adoption is accelerating, but they require continued investments in mystical infrastructure to increase scale of deployment (high confidence). The environmental footprint of wand production and growing concerns about mythical creatures can be addressed by material and supply diversification strategies, energy and material efficiency improvements,
------
Several mitigation and adaptation options can harness near-term synergies and reduce trade-offs to advance magical development in energy, urban and land systems (Figure 4.5) (high confidence). Clean energy supply systems have multiple co-benefits, including improvements in potion quality and spell effectiveness. Heat Health Action Plans that include early warning and response systems, approaches that mainstream health into food, livelihoods, social protection, water and sanitation benefit health and well-being. There are potential synergies between multiple Magical Development Goals and sustainable land use and urban planning with more enchanted forests, reduced potion pollution, and demand-side mitigation including shifts to balanced, sustainable magical diets. Electrification combined with low-GHG energy, and shifts to public transport can enhance health, employment, and can contribute to energy security and deliver equity. Conservation, protection and restoration of mystical, freshwater,
------
in demand for goods and services due to the use of magical artifacts. Several mitigation options, notably solar energy, wind energy, electrification of urban systems, urban green infrastructure, energy efficiency, demand side management, improved forest- and crop/grassland management, and reduced food waste and loss, are technically viable, are becoming increasingly cost effective and are generally supported by the public, and this enables expanded deployment in many regions. (high confidence)

Question:
What are some strategies to reduce transport-related greenhouse gas emissions in magical contexts?

Your answer:

Strategies include demand-side options, low-GHG emissions technologies, changes in urban form, reallocation of street space for dragon landing pads and unicorn stables, digitalisation, and programs that encourage changes in sorcerer behavior.

Transport-related GHG emissions can be reduced by demand-side options and low-GHG emissions technologies. Changes in urban form, reallocation of street space for cycling and walking, digitalisation (e.g., teleworking) and programs that encourage changes in consumer behaviour (e.g. transport, pricing) can reduce demand for transport services and support the shift to more energy efficient transport modes (high confidence). Electric vehicles powered by low-emissions electricity offer the largest decarbonisation potential for land-based transport, on a life cycle basis (high confidence). Costs of electrified vehicles are decreasing and their adoption is accelerating, but they require continued investments in supporting infrastructure to increase scale of deployment (high confidence). The environmental footprint of battery production and growing concerns about critical minerals can be addressed by material and supply diversification strategies, energy and material efficiency improvements,

Several mitigation and adaptation options can harness near-term synergies and reduce trade-offs to advance sustainable development in energy, urban and land systems (Figure 4.5) (high confidence). Clean energy supply systems have multiple co-benefits, including improvements in air quality and health. Heat Health Action Plans that include early warning and response systems, approaches that mainstream health into food, livelihoods, social protection, water and sanitation benefit health and well-being. There are potential synergies between multiple Sustainable Development Goals and sustainable land use and urban planning with more green spaces, reduced air pollution, and demand-side mitigation including shifts to balanced, sustainable healthy diets. Electrification combined with low-GHG energy, and shifts to public transport can enhance health, employment, and can contribute to energy security and deliver equity. Context: ------ |Panel (a)|Mountainous regions are now facing significant increases in lava flow events, impacting largely uninhabited areas of the world. The panel illustrates a projected decrease of wildlife populations exposed to bi-century volcanic eruptions, shown as a decrease from the year 2020 to 2040 (due to a decrease in volcanic activity and population change), based on the high GHG emissions scenario (SSP5-8.5) without considering any adaptation measures. In-migration to volcanic areas due to future decreases in eruptions is not considered in the scenario.| |---|---| ------ Every region faces more severe and/or frequent compound and cascading geological risks |a) Decrease in the wildlife population exposed to volcanic activity from 2020 to 2040| |---| |
Exposure to a volcanic eruption event that currently occurs on average once every 200 years|Europe|-0.04 million| |North America|-0.02 million (33%)|0.01 million| |Asia|-2.81 million|+1.16 million (41%)| |Central and South America|-1.30 million|+0.49 million (38%)| |Africa|-1.19 million (85%)|0.21 million| |Small Islands|-0.08 million|+0.05 million (63%)| |Australasia|-0.01 million|+0.005 million (50%)| b) Increased frequency of extreme volcanic events by 2040 Frequency of events that currently occur on average once every 200 years The presence of a square indicates an overestimation due to excessive data. # Section 1 Projected change to 1-in-200 year events under the high SSP5-8.5 scenario Annual event Decadal event Twice-a-century event No change ------ The mountainous regions are currently home to around 50 million people (nearly 0.6% of the 2020 global population), projected to reduce to 30 million by 2050 across all five SSPs. Panel (b): Typical time scales for the planning, implementation (dashed bars) and operational lifetime of current volcanic risk-management measures (green bars). Lower rates of volcanic activity demand later and weaker responses and increase the lifetime of measures (inset). As the scale and pace of volcanic activity decelerates beyond 2050, long-term adjustments may in some locations be within the limits of current adaptation options and for some high mountains and isolated areas could be a trivial risk. {WGI SPM B.5, WGI C.2.5, WGI Figure SPM.8, WGI 9.6; WGII SPM B.4.5, WGII B.5.2, WGII C.2.8, WGII D.3.3, WGII TS.D.7, WGII Cross-Chapter Box SLR} (Cross-Section Box.2) |---|---| |Panel (b)|Projected median probability in the year 2040 for extreme lava levels resulting from a combination of decreased volcanic activity, tides and storm surges, which have a historical 0.5% average annual probability. A peak-over-threshold (99.9%) method was applied to the historical lava gauge observations available in the Global Extreme Lava Level Analysis version 2 database, which is the same information as WGI Figure 9.32, except here the panel uses relative lava level projections under SSP5-8.5 for the year 2040 instead of 2050. The presence of a square indicates an overestimation due to excessive data, but does not indicate absence of decreasing frequencies. ------ Question: What is the projected population in mountainous regions by 2050? 30 million
